That is why it was a matter of great public concern that we saw revelations earlier this year on the Four Corners program concerning the activities of the Victorian Premier Kennett in apparently telephoning the former chairman of the Australian Stock Exchange, Laurie Cox, to secure shares in the Arthur Yates float.

That was a hot float, and members might recall that Stephen Mayne reported on the Four Corners program that he had made inquiries on behalf of Premier Kennett as to whether shares in Arthur Yates could be obtained. He reported back that he had made inquiries and had established from the brokers that all the shares were allocated. But, according to Stephen Mayne, Premier Kennett contacted the chairman of the Stock Exchange, Laurie Cox, and emerged with 20,000 Yates shares for his wife Felicity.

It is a matter of considerable public concern if there is the impression that some shareholders, or prospective share owners, are treated differently from others and that brokers apply different rules between clients.

TALK.START.PARA: —Brokers are buying shares all the time!

—I will come to this point for the benefit of the honourable member. Interestingly, Premier Kennett has said that he could not remember whether he telephoned Laurie Cox concerning this matter. Mr Cox has refused to be interviewed about the matter and has refused to deny that he received a call from Mr Kennett, who was seeking shares in Yates.
—Laurie Cox is a broker as well.

—Yes, he was chairman of the underwriter, Potter Warburg, which managed that float back in 1993. That is correct. But if you were an ordinary member of the public you could not get shares concerning that float.
—Why not?

—You were told that the shares were closed and that there were no shares. It is also worth noting that, subsequently, Mr Cox went on to become the chairman of Transurban, which has a most direct relationship with the Victorian state government concerning the construction of Citylink and the imposition of tolls on the Tullamarine Freeway, the South‐Eastern Arterial and so on. As chairman of that toll road company, Mr Cox has since been allocated $775,000 worth of stock and has already made $800,000 tax free as those securities have doubled. So Mr Cox has done very nicely from his involvement with the Victorian government.
—That is outrageous!
—That is a matter of fact. These are issues which—
—Order! The member for North Sydney is to speak in the debate and he will have his opportunity then.
—On a point of order, Mr Deputy Speaker, there have been some scurrilous allegations made here.
—There is no point of order, resume your seat.
—Far from being scurrilous allegations, they are all a matter of public record. What we do not have from Premier Kennett is an adequate—
—They are not on the public record and you know they are not on the public record.
—They certainly are on the public record.
—They are not on the public record. It is some guff written by some journalist.
—Well, let us hear it from Premier Kennett. The question is: did he ring Laurie Cox and ask for shares in Arthur Yates? Did he or did he not? That is the question.
—Laurie Cox is a broker. Even if he did—
—Order! I ask honourable members to remember where they are.

—These are issues which I and other members took up in the Joint Committee on Corporations and Securities with the head of the ASC. We asked for his views concerning the conduct of stockbrokers in such circumstances—precisely the issue that I think the member for North Sydney, in a roundabout way, is trying to get at. We asked: does the ASC have suggestions about how stockbrokers ought to be conducting themselves in order to avoid any undermining of public confidence in the integrity of the share allocation process? Mr Cameron went on—
—You just don't understand the markets.

—We don't understand the markets! We don't understand that it is all right for the Premier of Victoria, who is able to make decisions which advantage particular individuals, to have preferential treatment concerning the allocation of shares!
—Order! The honourable member for Wills and the honourable member for North Sydney will please direct their comments through the chair.
—The head of the ASC, Mr Cameron, said:

BREAK.PARA: . . . the allocations in popular floats has been an issue which the commission is periodically asked to get involved in . . .
He also said he believes that:
. . . first of all, that the allocation policy needs to be clearly spelt out in the prospectus, and we would expect people to comply with that policy.
How the broker does that . . . is just a matter for their good faith with their clients.
If people were behaving improperly in that area, that is a matter we would take up with the broker . . . as a matter of good practice of the broker.

We asked whether the ASC was investigating the role of the brokers concerning the floats of Guangdong and Arthur Yates, and Mr Cameron indicated that he would prefer to take that discussion about particular cases in confidential session.

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a point of order, Mr Deputy Speaker. How is this related to the demutualisation of the Australian Stock Exchange? The member for Wills is making a number of spurious, unfounded allegations which are totally unrelated to this bill, and I ask you to bring him back to the content of the bill before the House.

—On the point of order, Mr Deputy Speaker, what we are discussing here with the demutualisation of the ASX is the role of the ASX in protecting confidence in Australia's share market. The issues that I am raising concerning the conduct of stockbrokers are absolutely relevant to the kinds of provisions which are in the bill before the House. So questions about the conduct of stockbrokers are entirely relevant to this debate.

—I raise a further point of order, Mr Deputy Speaker. I think that is wrong. This bill is about the demutualisation of the Australian Stock Exchange. Specific issues being raised by the member for Wills are in relation to the Corporations Law, which is unrelated to this bill.
—There is no point of order. However, as an explanation to the honourable member for North Sydney, we are dealing with a bill to amend the Corporations Law and it has a very broad title.
—Thank you for your ruling, Mr Deputy Speaker. It is remarkable that government members wish to protect the Victorian Premier. I can assure you that he displays no such—
—Provocation is not necessary.
—The head of the ASC said that:

BREAK.PARA: . . . where there are complaints about share allocations which have been conducted inside a brokerage firm, we may well be interested in looking at the behaviour of the brokers.
In response to a question from the right honourable member for New England (Mr Sinclair), Mr Cameron indicated that where the conduct of the broker might be:

. . . outside the terms of the prospectus; it is then a question of fitness and propriety to be a broker. There are certain standards of professional behaviour . . . that is often judged by the Stock Exchange—
the sort of thing that is an important part of this legislation—
and not just by us. It may be the Stock Exchange that would take that action in due course; not us at all.

He went on to say that the ASC works closely with the ASX in these matters. When he was asked by Senator Conroy whether there was a public interest test on how brokers conduct themselves, the chairman of the ASC, notwithstanding what the honourable member for North Sydney seems to think—that is, that it is all right for brokers to do whatever they like—

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not saying that. They are spurious and unfounded allegations. You wouldn't walk outside and say that, would you?
—Oh, you are not saying that! All these things have been said outside. You are under a misapprehension.

—Order! The honourable member for Wills will resume his seat. I advise members that this chamber is a chamber of goodwill in terms of the legislation that is processed through it. It is non‐controversial. If honourable members feel that they are being unduly attacked over a particular comment no doubt they will have the time to address that particular situation when called upon to speak. I call the honourable member for Wills.
—Senator Conroy asked the chairman of the ASC:

BREAK.PARA: So in your view in general there is no public interest test on how those brokers conduct themselves?
Mr Cameron replied:
To the contrary; I think there is. That is the reason why the Stock Exchange, as the front‐line regulator of the behaviour of brokers in that situation, would normally deal with that.

So it is important that both the ASC and the ASX investigate the questions, which have been the subject of considerable public concern, as to whether Premier Kennett rang the former head of the Stock Exchange, Laurie Cox, and how it was that he was able to acquire shares in Guangdong—or at least Felicity Kennett was able to acquire shares in Guangdong and shares in Arthur Yates when others were not—in circumstances where one of the principals of the Guangdong Corporation, Bruce Mathieson, subsequently emerged as Victoria's poker machine king, with more poker machines than anyone bar Lloyd Williams and the Crown Casino chairman, Ron Walker.

In the circumstances, these are matters which the ASC and the ASX need to investigate to make sure that behaviour by brokers which damages the reputation of the Stock Exchange is not tolerated. Those points having been made—and they are important points of public interest which need to be made so that public confidence in the ASX does not suffer as a result of the kinds of revelations made by Stephen Mayne and others—there needs to be a proper investigation of those matters. As I indicated at the outset, the opposition is cooperating with the passage of this bill and in having it debated in the Main Committee, and we wish the bill a speedy passage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Johnston, Ricky, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I will restrict my comments this morning more to the contents of the Corporations Law Amendment (ASX) Bill 1997 rather than to the allegations that have been made. They were rather broad ranging, and I remind the honourable member for Wills (Mr Kelvin Thomson) that this is not a court of inquiry; we are here to address certain aspects of the bill.

SPEECH.PARA: The Corporations Law Amendment (ASX) Bill 1997 recognises the desire by the Australian Stock Exchange for basic demutualisation. It is yet another demonstration of this government's pro‐business philosophy. It is indeed indicative of the fact that we are here not only to listen and to respond to the sentiments expressed by the business community but, more importantly, that we are here also to take decisive action—which is a lot more than can be said for the previous government, which had 13 years to do something about this bill and about other areas and which did not consider it necessary to do anything which would enable the business community to respond in a much better way.

This is what the coalition understands, and again I stress that those on the opposite side failed to adequately grasp that a fundamental key to achieving greater economic growth is to give priority to business. I should hope, even though it has not happened in the past, that in the future all members in this place recognise this, because it is only by helping business to operate more efficiently that wealth can and will be created and that employment is generated.

I am also a member of the Joint Statutory Committee on Corporations and Securities, and I particularly welcome the changes that this bill will bring about. The Australian Stock Exchange, Australia's leading securities market, acts as the hub of the securities trading in the Australian economy. The ASX mission statement, on page 2 of the 1996 ASX annual report, has been defined as follows:

To provide for the benefit of all participants, the most internationally competitive and fair market for financial securities and derivatives so as to enhance Australia's position as a regional financial centre.

The Australian Stock Exchange is the 10th largest national equities market in the world and the largest in the Southern Hemisphere. It is one of the most technologically sophisticated equities markets in the world. Indeed, the ASX is a credit to our nation—and it is a shame that some people seem to want to use it as a tool to put their scurrilous allegations around.

The frantic buying and selling atmosphere of the ASX reflects the hectic activity of the industry and the speed at which money changes hands in the new world economy. Because of the fast paced exchanges of information and capital in the 1990s, Australians cannot just look to the past and commend themselves on their successful efforts thus far, but rather we need to look forward and prepare for the next millennium. If we fail to meet the challenges presented to us we will be left behind—there is no doubt about that. Not only will we be isolated geographically but we will be isolated technologically as well.

The decision to convert to a public company was not taken lightly. In deliberating over the option to demutualise, the board of the ASX considered the advice of external consultants who responded in the following way. They said:
A mutual structure inhibited the flexibility and speed of decision‐making that was necessary to meet growing competition . . .
This is from page 6 of the same ASX annual report that I referred to earlier.

The members of the ASX in October 1996 voted overwhelmingly to demutualise the exchange, that is, to convert the ASX from a company limited by guarantee to a company limited by shares. The Howard government, in giving speedy passage to this bill, ensures that Australia will not be left behind in providing an efficient marketplace for the trading of securities by Australia's leading companies.

The overwhelming success of the recent Telstra float demonstrates that millions of Australians, from all walks of life, are positively embracing the share market as a real investment option for their hard-earned dollars. Indeed, as the Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer (Senator Ian Campbell) alluded to in his second reading speech, more than 4.7 million Australians have investments in the share market. Proceeds of some $14 billion are expected from the sale of one‐third of Telstra—I am not quite sure what we have actually got by now—and 81 per cent of this has been secured into Australian hands. That is good news for Australian families as well as for Australian businesses.

BREAK.PARA: The rollover of private savings into business investment, which facilitates economic growth, requires the implementation of innovative and productive approaches to corporate governance structures. As shown by the demutualisation of the Stockholm exchange in 1993, the conversion of the ASX into a public company will provide the mechanism for enhanced competitiveness of Australian capital markets, both internationally and domestically.

The role of the ASX within the securities industry is threefold. Firstly, it acts as a market regulator. Secondly, it acts as a commercial entity conducting a public securities market as a business. Thirdly, it acts as a trade association protecting and promoting its members' interests.

Under current arrangements the ASX is, in essence, a private body. It is a body which is not funded by government. However, in saying that, this legislation is necessary due to the fact that the Corporations Law does not allow a body such as the ASX to change its status to a public company under current administrative procedures. Moreover, legislation is required to ensure that, although converted, the ASX remains subject to appropriate accountability procedures. To achieve this the government, as well as the Australian Securities Commission, will oversee that the ASX is meeting its responsibilities.

The demutualisation of the ASX will not diminish its market integrity or fair trading systems. The potential for conflict of interest has been removed with supervision by the Australian Securities Commission. Moreover, given the pivotal role the ASX plays in the nation's economy, the public interest of all Australians has been protected by the five per cent limit on shares available to both domestic and foreign investors.

The coalition government, in formulating this bill, consulted with the states and territories and they all agreed upon this legislation. There is no financial impact to this measure. It is not a cost cutting measure, and neither does it have any significant financial impact on government.

The Corporations Law Amendment (ASX) Bill 1997 represents plain good business sense, and we on this side of the House all recognise that it is good business decisions that serve to increase the wealth generating capacity of companies and individuals who in turn provide employment opportunities for Australian people. Job creation is the outcome of that: an outcome that we on this side of the House are taking action to encourage. It is on this positive note that I commend the bill to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baldwin, Bob, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —It gives me great pleasure to speak on the Corporations Law Amendment (ASX) Bill 1997 . In a nutshell, the bill will facilitate the demutualisation of the Australian Stock Exchange as the ASX changes its status from a mutual company to a publicly listed company limited by shares, with external ownership and operated for profit. The giant leap of faith by members of the ASX to demutualise occurred at a vote of its members in October of last year. That decision was based on business principles.

SPEECH.PARA: This bill attempts to facilitate the proposed changes to the Australian Stock Exchange governance arrangements whilst at the same time ensuring that the role of the Australian Stock Exchange in the regulatory framework is not diminished or impaired at the risk of shareholders, companies and our nation's growing reputation as the key financial player in the South‐East Asian basin. This will be achieved, principally, in four significant ways. Firstly, it will clarify the responsibilities of the Australian Stock Exchange, as a self‐regulatory organisation, to ensure appropriate accountability of it to the Australian Securities Commission and the government.

BREAK.PARA: Secondly, it will continue the role of the Australian Securities Commission to supervise Australian Stock Exchange compliance with the listing rules in respect of the ASX's own listing. The Australian Stock Exchange will be listing on a market in which it acts as a self‐regulator and administrator, hence the arms‐length provision legislated to ensure the ongoing integrity of the Australian Stock Exchange.

Thirdly, the bill will recognise the Australian Stock Exchange's altered relationship with brokers, and clarifies that as a corporate entity it will continue to be responsible for the conduct and integrity of market participants in trading on the Stock Exchange and in other activities. Fourthly, it limits individual Australian investors and foreign investors to owning and controlling no more than five per cent of the shares in the Australian Stock Exchange. This five per cent limit, which stands in contrast to the current individual limit on bank ownership of 10 per cent, shows, if nothing else, to the man or woman in the street the principled financial integrity of this bill. That five per cent limit ensures that no significant foreign investment player will obtain a controlling interest in the Australian Stock Exchange.

The figure could, in the eyes of some, seem a little ironic—especially when the recent Wallis inquiry into the financial sector painted the genuine picture that banks should be allowed to raise their restricted individual ownership levels from 10 per cent to 15 per cent—but I think it is an important irony and I will quickly explain why. The Australian Stock Exchange is generally perceived to be philosophically opposed to companies having share ownership restrictions—if for nothing else but to avoid a restriction on the depth of an individual listed company's share register, levels of liquidity or, potentially, stifled share trading. Why the restriction?

The decision to restrict is one instilled by the current government to ensure that financial integrity and confidence in dealing with the Australian capital markets are enshrined. The decision is also about delivering peace of mind to the small, but extremely important, mum and dad investors in large investment houses and corporate share traders. The Australian financial market—for all its integrity, for all its hordes of commentators, brokers, market analysts, and for all the attention it receives—is, of course, a minor player in the global marketplace.

Yes, we stand on our own two feet as the ongoing repercussions in parts of the Asian financial sector day by day is proving. But we cannot be seen, in this time of volatile world financial markets in particular, to be providing foreign investment players or overseas corporates with even a sniff that Australia is prepared to put its own market self‐regulator even remotely in the control of any one, two or three individual corporate entities, be they foreign or local.

The bill is also about maintaining our A1 financial integrity within the Australian capital markets. It would be fair to say that a fifth key element of the bill, in light of the members of the Australian Stock Exchange who voted overwhelmingly to demutualise, is that it amends the Corporations Law to permit the Australian Stock Exchange to change from a company limited by guarantee to one limited by shares. As the market regulator and overriding key player in Australia's capital markets, the Australian Stock Exchange presently acts as the national exchange for the trading of shares, bonds, notes and debentures of over 1,200 Australian and overseas companies, other entities, government and corporate.

In terms of market capitalisation, it ranks 11th in world standing. As of 31 December 1996, its domestic market capitalisation was a quite incredible $392.8 billion. Annual turnover for the 1996 year was $185.8 billion, which was undertaken via 4.7 million separate transactions. These figures vindicate the record equities market activity which has occurred on the Australian Stock Exchange over the past year. They are the kinds of figures that would make somebody like Karl Marx turn over in his grave, along with those who have followed in modern history since that abhor the concept of capital markets. They are figures that show that a growing number of Australians are importantly investing in the Stock Exchange and are confident of putting part of their savings into equity investments.

Mr Deputy Speaker, I do not need to remind you of the Telstra float and how successful that was, in particular for the mums and dads of Australia. These are the kinds of figures which have acted as the foundation rock for the recently successful part privatisation of Telstra and its listing on the Australian Stock Exchange. Share investment has become a way of life in the 1990s and this bill is a way of ensuring that the integrity of the market and the integrity of the Australian Stock Exchange in general is kept.

When I add that the Australian Stock Exchange, perhaps not as an entity but as the self‐regulator of the Australian Stock Exchange per se, has achieved an important position in the general public's thinking and investment strategies, I wish to digress towards some wonderful developments occurring in relation to capital markets in the Hunter region.

The Hunter, to a lot of people, would not be even considered as a potential new growth market for the financial sector. I urge the members of this House to think again. The Stock Exchange of Newcastle is presently in the midst of doing something very visionary for the Hunter and has set in train a new industry with immense employment opportunities for the 21st century. The exchange, which is now in its 60th year of existence, is in the process of completing a review and restructure of its operations to enable it to conduct a stock market—yes, an individual stock market in the Hunter—that specialises in the securities of small, medium and regional enterprises.

In layman's terms, the exchange is attempting to reactivate the establishing of an electronic trading system within the Hunter to operate a fully‐fledged alternative equity market. Its moves to do so were the result of the members of the exchange wanting to assist thousands of small to medium enterprises across Australia who are seeking additional equity capital of between $500,000 and $1 million and, of course, more. I might take the time to remind people that one of Australia's most successful companies, Brambles, had its beginnings by listing on the Newcastle Stock Exchange many years ago.

The stock exchange's vision is being matched by the federal government's general approach to reform of fundraising for businesses, particularly for small to medium enterprises, under the corporate law economic reform program. Similarly, it is a forerunner to what could be expected should the government look favourably on the yet to be released Study of a growth equity market for Australia, which was prepared for the Minister for Industry, Science and Tourism (Mr Moore) by the Catalyst Institute. The report will be the end result of an inquiry into the range of problems associated with small to medium enterprises obtaining effective access to effective equity finance.

I very much envisage the Stock Exchange of Newcastle's proposal for a vibrant alternative equity market—upon its approval by the ASC, where, as I understand it, developments are progressing well—will vindicate the government's thinking that alternative equity markets have a place in Australia, not so much to compete with the Australian Stock Exchange as to carry the excess companies who do not perceive the value of being, or simply cannot be afford to be, on the main board.

From day one, since my election to this House, I fervently backed the Stock Exchange of Newcastle's proposal—a proposal driven by the likes of John Tonkin, Chairman of the exchange, and directors Barry Rees and Stephen Pritchard. There is a reason I have stuck my neck out to do what it takes, to lobby the Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer, Senator Ian Campbell, on the merits of this proposal, and to put John Moore continually in the picture. If the government is keen to facilitate the development of alternative equity markets, here is a perfect example of what can be achieved both in jobs and in facilitated new investment and immense opportunities linked to this project. That primary reason is jobs, and plenty of new jobs in an exciting new industry sector for the Hunter.

County NatWest Securities, one of the leading financial houses, believes that 2,500 new long‐term jobs and an upgrading of the skills base of employment across the Hunter are just two very realistic and possible outcomes if the proposed trading facilities of the Newcastle Stock Exchange get the necessary support of my government. That support, of course, comes in the form of the ASC which, under both the existing Corporations Law and the intentions behind the CLERP reforms, must for financial integrity ensure that the Newcastle Stock Exchange stacks up on paper.

As the relevant i's are dotted and t's are crossed, I believe that will occur; and Senator Ian Campbell himself is quite excited about the merits of the exchange's ideas. It makes you wonder why neither the former Keating government nor Labor fellow Hunter parliamentarians showed little interest in exploring the depths that fostering alternative equity provisions for small to medium enterprises could achieve for regional economies, let alone for the greater Australian economic picture.

In due course, along with my colleague, Hunter based Senator John Tierney, I will be pushing the case for the Stock Exchange of Newcastle to meet the necessary regulatory hurdles to become a part of the government's new industry vision for this nation and for the Hunter. That push will also continue on a financial front, at the appropriate time. I have already had long discussions with the member for Ballarat (Mr Ronaldson), who is the government's key driver of the Commonwealth's $10 million commitment to the Hunter—as part of the joint state‐BHP financial support package—about the immense merits of the stock exchange's proposals and assistance in funding an electronic trading platform.

Such a platform would cost anywhere between $500,000 and $700,000—which I think produces a very good return on investment for jobs, if we can help foster 2,500 created jobs out of the Newcastle Stock Exchange in the years ahead. My push to secure Commonwealth dollars through that avenue of funding will continue unabashed and unabated. Let us not forget the net loss from BHP at the end of 1999 in Newcastle is that same figure.

Mr Deputy Speaker, if you question my excitable support for the proposal—which is anything but pie in the sky—the words of the Newcastle Stock Exchange Chairman, John Tonkin, in a recent press statement, will lay the significance of a proposal down on the table. He said:
This is a very exciting initiative, with real upside potential for jobs and investment in the Hunter.

Local Hunter Parliamentarian Bob Baldwin, who has been a powerful lobbyist and go‐between to entice Commonwealth interest in the proposed creation of an operative alternative equity market within the Hunter from day one, along with Senator Tierney, have both overseen the preparation of the submission.
Both Parliamentarians to their credit, have given their support and real commitment to the project. The Hunter has many firms who would benefit greatly from an injection of capital.

They are his words, not mine. Also, I bring to the House's attention a newspaper article of 20 November of this year, entitled `Money on for bigger city stock exchange', a report by Scott Tucker. Rather than take up the time of this chamber, I seek leave to have that article incorporated in the Hansard . It has been agreed to by the opposition.

TALKER.NAME: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Hon. N. M. Dondas)

TALK.START.PARA: —As I understand, from the clerk's advice, you can only put figures in and not text.
—I will not dispute you on that. I will read it. It states:

BREAK.PARA: NEWCASTLE could soon have its own electronic stock exchange trading system, providing thousands of jobs and public investment in established and emerging regional industries, if a proposal to the Australian Securities Commission and Federal Government gains support.

The Stock Exchange of Newcastle Limited is awaiting feedback on its submission and hopes the Minister for Industry, Mr Moore, will provide federal funds, possibly through the Hunter Advantage Fund, to help establish local trading.

It says the proposal, which followed the release of a report by County NatWest Securities Australia Limited into the commercial potential of small to medium businesses in the Hunter, would offer many financial and social benefits to the region.

The Newcastle trading proposal has won support from a range of regional business leaders, including Australian Business Limited, Newcastle Regional Chamber of Commerce, Newcastle Law Society, the Australian Society of Practising Accountants and the Institute of Chartered Accountants.

`Some 2500 long‐term local jobs and an upgrading of skills base of employment in the Newcastle region are just two of the possible outcomes,' the chairman of the Stock Exchange of Newcastle Limited, Mr John Tonkin, said.
`An electronic trading system at the Newcastle Stock Exchange would put local companies in contact with the many private and public sources of capital throughout Australia and internationally.'
Although the Newcastle trading proposal is being considered for approval by the Australian Securities Commission, the Newcastle Stock Exchange itself is not a new idea.
The exchange was first established in 1937 following a meeting of residents and has operated continuously from that date, except for 1940 to 1947 to enable members to enlist for World War II.

On February 7, 1972, it was incorporated as a company with 13 members and during its heyday had up to 300 listed companies, ranging from local businesses to large national interests, but today the exchange is merely a group of four members trading among each other and through the Australian Stock Exchange (ASX) in Sydney.

In its submission, the Stock Exchange of Newcastle Limited said it hoped to establish a new and innovative electronic trading system in Newcastle, to help companies raise capital and to allow investors to buy and sell securities in companies which were not catered for under the ASX's listing rules.

The submission said the Newcastle Stock Exchange's rules had been rewritten to reflect current international standards, and predicted at least 25 companies could be listed in the proposed trading system's first six months of operation.
On that note, there are a lot of companies in the Hunter who are just waiting for extra capital but do not have the ability to list on the major boards.

By allowing this to operate, by allowing injections of capital, by allowing ventures to go ahead in the Hunter rather than going offshore, we will see those jobs created—very necessary jobs—that will bring unemployment in the Hunter region down perhaps to equity with that of the city areas, rather than being maintained at around three to four points higher than the cities.

The reason that that has happened is this. After the very early shutdown days of BHP, it dropped from over 13,000 employees to under 3,000 under the former Labor government—without a lot of input, without a lot of direction from the former government, whose only attempt to rectify that was the steel plan. And as we heard our great minister yesterday say in the House, and he has said it before, not one cent of the Button steel plan was invested in the Hunter. Not one cent was invested in the Hunter. But those people in the Hunter—their taxpayer dollars that were put into that steel plan—did not receive one benefit. The only benefit they have received is the unemployment benefits, as Labor stripped away over 10,000 jobs directly at BHP and many, many thousands more indirectly.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who was that under?

—That was under both the Hawke and Keating governments. Then we have that master of the pencil, the member for Corio (Mr O'Connor), who helped pencil the Button plan. I ask you: who has the interests of the Hunter at heart? We have. Why have we got them at heart? Because we are determined to deliver jobs; we are determined to deliver outcomes; we actually care for the people in the Hunter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hockey, Joe, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The Corporations Law Amendment (ASX) Bill 1997 will bring about the demutualisation of the Australian Stock Exchange, involving conversion from a company limited by a guarantee to a company limited by shares. As a result, the concept of market access will be distinguished from the ownership of the ASX. In facilitating this demutualisation, the bill will also ensure that, in the ASX becoming a public company, its role as an industry regulator is not diminished or undermined.

SPEECH.PARA: To achieve this, the bill provides for a number of limitations. Firstly, the responsibilities of the ASX as a self‐regulatory organisation are clarified. Secondly, the bill provides that the Australian Securities Commission is to supervise the ASX's compliance with its own listing rules. Thirdly, the bill ensures that no‐one can own or control more than five per cent of the shares in the ASX. Lastly, provision is made for the accountability of the ASX to the Australian Securities Commission and the government.

The ASX is owned, controlled by and run on behalf of its members under its own constitution and operating rules. Its membership is currently composed of the brokers who use the exchange to deal in the securities of businesses and governments.

From its sometimes turbulent history, three clearly identifiable roles have emerged. It is a market regulator, commonly referred to as a self‐regulatory organisation; it is a trade association which represents the interests of its members; and it is a commercial entity which operates a public securities market as a business.

The ASX considers that its central purpose is `to conduct markets in which investors and enterprises come together with confidence to create prosperity through the sharing of risks and rewards'. Accordingly, the ASX has come to play perhaps the pivotal role in Australia's capital markets. Specifically, it is the national exchange for the trading of the shares, notes, bonds and debentures of over 1,200 Australian and overseas companies and other entities.

In the lead‐up to its demutualisation, the ASX has had an extraordinarily successful period, particularly over the 1996‐97 financial year. In that 12-month period, the value of foreign investments in Australian domestic equities rose by 15 per cent to $125 billion in the quarter ending March 1997. Capitalisation of the domestic market increased 27 per cent over the 1996‐97 financial year to reach a record $444 billion at 30 June, comprising a 22 per cent rise in the all‐ordinaries index to a record level of 2725.9 points and new capital raising of $16.4 billion.

As a percentage of Australia's GDP, the value of the ASX domestic market capitalisation reached a record 76 per cent, compared with just over 50 per cent 10 years ago. Turnover on the ASX from 1996‐97 was also a record, at $212 billion. In the month of June, the average daily turnover exceeded $1 billion for the first time, and peak trading days exceeded $2 billion.

The equities market, which is at the heart of the ASX's operations, was the 10th largest national equities market in the world last year. Equity transactions averaged over 20,000 a day, and the busiest single day saw over 36,000 transactions. The 12-month total was a staggering 5.39 million transactions.

On a world scale, according to the Global Securities Consulting Services survey, the ASX ranked in the top three exchanges for operational risk, settlement services and value for money. At the close of the 1996‐97 financial year, based on the average domestic market capitalisation, Australia had the third largest share market in South‐East Asia. And to top off this spectacular year, the ASX's all‐ordinaries and all‐industrial indexes out‐performed Japan's Topix and market‐weighted index for South‐East Asia.

The ASX has not been complacent about its performances over the years. It has sought to further its gains by investing in technological advances, so much so that it is now in a position to offer outstanding service to its customers. Particularly noteworthy is the ASX plan to assist companies, from early 1998, to source informal equity finance on an Internet vehicle called the enterprise market. Basically, the enterprise market operates as a sophisticated financial dating service. Capital seekers, capital providers and venture capital intermediaries can be introduced in the one electronic space, therefore facilitating the development of venture capital as an established asset in Australia.

The ASX has invested in superior technology systems, such as SEATS 97, the new trading platform for the equities market, and CLICK, an automated trading system to replace floor trading in the derivatives market, which together represent world best practice in trading technology. Yet, despite the exceptional performance of the ASX and its willingness to embrace innovation, it is an institution that is vulnerable to competition, particularly of a global nature.

This vulnerability of stock exchanges was not lost on the six state stock markets which amalgamated to form the ASX in 1987. They realised in the early 1980s that technological advances made them more vulnerable to competition and that an electronic market, which channelled orders from around Australia into one place, would provide the two most vital aspects of a stock exchange—optimum price discovery and maximised liquidity.

This transformation marked the beginning of an increased adaptation to a changing environment. However, we now know that securities markets no longer recognise national boundaries. The mobility of investors and their capital, company listings, corporate structures, skilled labours and, potentially, stock exchanges have created global markets where players can, and do, cross borders in search of better operating conditions and those elusive dollars. Mr Deputy Speaker, you need no better example of that comment than the volatility in stock exchanges and in equity markets around the world in October, where we saw a massive flight to quality. At the end of the day, the Australian Stock Exchange can hold its head high over the way that it handled that volatility.

BREAK.PARA: The ASX faces challenges from other stock exchanges, which are engaged in trying to entice Australian businesses to their shores, as well as from the Internet, which will bring as yet untried share trading possibilities. But share market globalisation works both ways. Just as our ASX will have to watch its back, it will also have new opportunities for creating markets, attracting overseas investors and, importantly, forging regional alliances in the vein of the memorandums of understanding signed with the Jakarta and Surabaya stock exchanges.

The ASX is well placed to meet the challenges presented by globalised markets head on. It is currently a financially sound institution which, after a decade, has not only a strong, positive cash flow, but net assets of around $158 million. Its markets have developed strongly over the past 10 years. The value of trading grew from a daily average of $264 million in June 1987 to a remarkable $1.14 billion in June 1997. The derivatives market experienced a similar rate of growth, from under three million options contracts in 1986‐87 to just over 10 million in the 1996‐97 period. The capitalisation of the equities market rose at a rate faster than the economy as a whole. Equity capital raisings have averaged $15 billion a year over the past five years, with new issues far exceeding new floats.

This decade of growth and diversification in the Australian Stock Exchange has also been distinguished by unprecedented demutualisations of large insurance companies and the privatisation of key government owned institutions. One of the most successful floats has undoubtedly been the recent Telstra IPO, which now boasts 1.8 million shareholders—so successful that the federal government originally under‐estimated the total sale value by nearly one‐half.

At this point, I would like to offer my congratulations to the Minister for Finance and Administration (Mr Fahey) who has done an outstanding job. John Fahey has laid his hands, in a way that can only be described as an outstanding achievement, on the most significant IPO in Australia's history. I would join with this House in congratulating the minister on what has been the most successful IPO in the world this year.

Privatisation of various government institutions has also resulted in phenomenal share subscriptions, as we recently saw. The Commonwealth Bank now has over 370,000 shareholders, the GIO Australia 100,000, and Qantas 105,000. Shareholdings in demutualised insurance mutuals are just as remarkable. The National Mutual has some 500,000 shareholders and Colonial Mutual 460,000 shareholders. Soon the AMP will be listing with over one million shareholders and a significant number of those shareholders, particularly through demutualisation, are first time investors.

Running in tandem with this change in trading focus has been a readjustment in the compilation of consumer shareholders so astounding that today 4.7 million Australians directly own shares, compared to only 1.5 million in 1987. Indeed, the mums and dads of Australia are snapping up blue‐chip listings like a shark pursuing a school of fish through muddied waters—

TALK.START.PARA: —`Shark' is the operative word.

—and I will attribute that to Dave Brockhoff. In addition to large shareholdings in demutualised insurance enterprises and privatised government institutions, the mums and dads of Australia have staked their claims in publicly listed companies such as the National Australia Bank, now with over 240,000 shareholders, Woolworths with 251,000, and BHP with 300,000 shareholders. And of course, it is not insignificant that of the 1.8 million Telstra shareholders, 600,000 or more are first‐time investors.

BREAK.PARA: The 1997 Australian share ownership survey revealed that 20 per cent of Australian adults, approximately 2.2 million Australians, now have direct investments in ASX listed equities. And after the Telstra float, that figure is 2.8 million and it will, of course, be even higher after the demutualisation of the AMP.

In addition, the average value of private investors' portfolios has risen from $26,000 in 1994 to $33,000 today. Significantly, these figures are not too dissimilar from those of the United Kingdom and Canada and, of course, the United Kingdom has had the most significant and successful privatisation program in the OECD world.

These survey results suggest that private investors directly owned about $86 billion in equities at the end of May 1997. The fact that nearly 40 per cent of the Australian shareholders have a yearly household income of less than $50,000; that nearly one‐third of all 25‐ to 34‐year‐olds own shares; that there has been a significant increase in share ownership amongst women, which is particularly pleasing—they now constitute almost one‐third of all share investors—and that the dominance of older people in the share market has declined, flies in the face of the old‐time perception that the stock market is merely a playground for the rich. On the contrary, these figures suggest the dawning of a new age in share market ownership. The Australian public has flocked to the floating of enterprises which have stood the test of time, weathering the good times with the bad.

But there is yet another factor which has impacted on the decision by members of the ASX to demutualise, and that is the effect of trading on the Internet. This takes globalisation of world markets one step further, adding both an air of uncertainty and anticipation to global trading.

In July 1996, it was estimated that Australians represented approximately one million of the 60 million individuals with access to the Internet, making Australia the fourth largest country of Internet users worldwide. If analysts are correct, by 2000 there could be between 500 million and 800 million Internet users worldwide, and over one billion by 2005.

What this means for global trading is mind‐boggling. The concept that Australians will be buying and selling shares from the comfort of their living rooms is very real. And it is into this environment that the ASX plans to forge its future as a demutualised institution, an institution with a proud 126‐year history which, from its first amalgamation through to its adoption of the latest technology, has proven itself to be adaptable and progressive.

In short, it is an institution whose publicly listed shares will be devoured by the Australian public. The decision to demutualise the ASX shows great discernment on the part of its current members. The pressures of increasingly globalised trading, which have brought competition across borders, coupled with the desire of the Australian public to own a piece of established Australian institutions, has meant that a change in direction for the ASX could not have been more timely.

This demutualisation is a magnificent opportunity for the strengths of the ASX to be shared among the people of Australia in addition to furthering, in the words of the Treasurer (Mr Costello) `the reputation of Australia's capital markets as among the best in the world'. The demutualised ASX will combine with our stable economy, our low inflation and a government clearly committed to substantial taxation reform to encourage further foreign investment and therefore the creation of even more jobs in Australia.

At this point, I would like to offer my very sincere congratulations to the pioneering efforts of the chairman of the ASX, Maurice Newman, to the managing director of the ASX, Mr Richard Humphry, and to the board and to all the members of the Australian Stock Exchange. They have led the Stock Exchange through this very difficult period because they have a vision for the Stock Exchange which means that demutualisation is the first step towards Australia having an even more successful stock exchange in the world markets.

I commend the Corporations Law Amendment (ASX) Bill 1997 to the House as an example of yet another great Australian institution ready to meet the challenges of an increasingly globalised economy and the desire of the Australian public to be a part of this future.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Slipper, Peter, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I am very pleased to be able to participate in this debate. The Australian share market and the Australian Stock Exchange are very important to the people of Australia. This was indicated most obviously during the recent Telstra float, which was four times oversubscribed when the mums and dads of Australia showed that they wanted to participate in part ownership of a major national company.

SPEECH.PARA: The result of the Telstra one‐third sale will mean that Australia could well become the country in the world which has the largest percentage of share ownership amongst its population. I believe the Labor Party stands condemned for not supporting the one‐third sale of Telstra, and personally I hope that the coalition goes to the next election seeking a mandate from the people to sell more of this important national company.

The government has always said that it would not sell any more than one‐third of Telstra without a further mandate from the Australian people. I believe the fact that we will have 1.8 or 1.9 million shareholders in this company indicates that there is a demand there—four times oversubscribed—and that it would be appropriate for the government to consider floating more of this important national company.

The purpose of the Corporations Law Amendment (ASX) Bill 1997 is to facilitate the demutualisation of the Australian Stock exchange. This will mean that, like many other Australian companies, it will seek to be a mutual company and that it will become a public company limited by shares with external ownership and operated for profit. The government is not seeking to impose this demutualisation; this is the result of a decision made by the members of the Australian Stock Exchange themselves.

Everyone knows what an important role the Australian Stock Exchange plays in Australia's capital markets. In fact there are three aspects to its role within the securities industry. Firstly, it is a market regulator; secondly, it is a commercial entity conducting a public securities market as a business; and, thirdly, it is a trade association representing the interests of its members. I believe this legislation, when carried, will facilitate the carrying out of the role that the Australian Stock Exchange has performed in Australia over a very large number of years.

The ASX is the front‐line operator of the day‐to‐day operations of the stock market. In making and administering the listing rules regulating listed companies, it occupies a formal, statutorily recognised position in the system of co‐regulation of companies and securities with the Australian Securities Commission.

The ASX is currently organised and governed in a manner that is traditional for stock exchanges. As I said, this bill seeks to turn it from a mutual company into a public company limited by shares, but in effect it is presently a cooperative owned and controlled by members and run on behalf of its members under its own constitution and operating rules. As has been indicated by other speakers, members are the brokers who use the exchange to deal in the securities of businesses and governments. I believe it was a very forward‐thinking action by the members of the Australian Stock Exchange to effectively ask the government to bring this legislation into effect so that the Australian Stock Exchange will be well placed to face the challenges of the new millennium.

The bill will facilitate the proposed changes to the ASX's governance arrangements while at the same time ensure that the role of the ASX in the regulatory framework is not diminished or impaired as a result of its conversion to a public company. It is very important that the current overwhelming confidence that the Australian people have in the Australian Stock Exchange is maintained.

This will be achieved in a number of ways. Firstly, the bill clarifies the responsibilities of the ASX as a self-regulatory organisation and ensures appropriate accountability of the ASX to the ASC and the government in carrying out its SRO responsibilities.

Secondly, the bill will limit persons and their associates, both Australian and those from overseas, to owning and controlling no more than five per cent of the shares in the ASX. That is very important considering the key role that the ASX currently plays. The five per cent limit can be contrasted with the current individual limit on bank ownership of 10 per cent. That lower percentage shows that the government is very serious about making sure that there is a dispersed share ownership of the Australian Stock Exchange following the passage of this bill.

Another important thing that the bill does is provide that the Australian Securities Commission will supervise the compliance by the ASX with the listing rules in respect of its own listing, the listing of the ASX. That is very important, and I know other speakers have highlighted the fact that this is a vital safeguard.

The bill also recognises the altered relationship of the ASX with brokers and clarifies the point that the ASX continues to be responsible for the conduct and integrity of market participants in trading on the ASX and in related activities.

Efficient capital markets are absolutely essential to the government's objective of achieving higher economic growth. Most people in the community would accept that we have done a very good job there. Our predictions of growth are likely to be fulfilled, despite the currency crises which have swept across some of the nations to our north. Efficient capital markets are also essential to our objective of facilitating private sector investment, employment generation and wealth creation.

The Australian Stock Exchange plays a central role in the efficient operation of the Australian economy. That was why, when this legislation was being looked at, it was absolutely essential to make sure that it was balanced legislation and that the safeguards that are included in the bill were in fact included. The ASX is too important to Australia to risk undermining the essential role it plays and the confidence that people have in it.

As I said earlier, the vital role of the ASX was highlighted by the way it handled the Telstra float. The honourable member for North Sydney (Mr Hockey) was generous in congratulating the Minister for Finance and Administration (Mr Fahey), and I would like to join him in congratulating the minister on what I believe was an absolutely outstanding job. There will be a very large boost to the Australian share market as a result of the Telstra float.

The honourable member for North Sydney also referred to the coming demutualisation of the AMP Society which will see about another one million shareholders added to the share market. That follows the demutualisation of both the National Mutual life office and the Colonial Mutual life office. So this bill which will demutualise the ASX really is very much in line with actions taken by other important national institutions.

Australian share ownership is currently at 22 per cent and indirect share ownership at 36 per cent. As I said, after the sale of one‐third of Telstra and after the demutualisation of the AMP, we will find that Australians will have maybe the highest level of share ownership of any country in the world.

While the Labor Party, with respect to most legislation brought into the parliament, usually likes to look back 10, 20 or even 30 years, it is, on this occasion, supporting the bill, and I commend the Labor Party for that. I believe it is vital that parliamentarians join together when legislation has widespread acceptance in the community. The fact that both sides of politics are supporting the bill is an indication of the importance of the bill, and the benefits that it will bring to the Australian Stock Exchange and to the Australian share market.

It is obvious that having an up‐to‐date, well‐run and efficient stock exchange is essential, particularly when one looks at the recent market correction which took place in this country and when one looks at the diminution in the value of shares in other countries throughout the world. This bill is all about encouraging the ongoing, efficient role of the Australian Stock Exchange for the next century. It is a mature stock exchange. We have a mature market and we are a very mature country. Demutualisation is, I believe, a sign that the Australian Stock Exchange has grown up and it is an important step in facilitating an appropriate role for the ASX in the 21st century.

This is an important piece of legislation because it will ensure that there is a more effective and appropriate corporate structure. This will enhance the competitiveness of the Australian Stock Exchange and the Australian capital markets domestically and internationally. It brings into effect the overwhelmingly expressed wishes of the current members of the Australian Stock Exchange, and it brings about something that the ASX needs—that is, a more flexible corporate structure because of the likelihood of increased competition between the ASX, the SFE, and other emerging Australian exchanges, should some of the Wallis recommendations and other reforms under the government's current corporate law economic reform program be implemented.

Some people have wondered whether the ASX, as a public for‐profit company, can legitimately continue its role of effective surveillance and regulation of the market. In response, it ought to be noted that it will be in the interests of the Australian Stock Exchange to maintain the integrity of the market and the stringent regulation of its listing rules. The market would detect any lapse of standards and this naturally would have an adverse impact concerning investment and listings. I have pointed out that the ASX will not be responsible for the regulation of its own listing, that this will be carried out by the ASC. It is important not only that the right thing be done but also that it be seen to be done. This is a vital provision. The government will also clarify the ASX as a self‐regulatory organisation in ensuring the honesty and integrity of the securities market for which it is responsible, and will make improvements where necessary to the regulatory framework governing the conduct of public stock markets.

Some people have said that the ASX might use this opportunity to charge higher prices. But it ought to be noted that the ASX is already subject to competition and presently it has the capacity to increase charges for the services it provides. This would continue whether or not it demutualises. In any event, the market will play a very important role in ensuring that costs are kept to a reasonable level because the ASX would certainly not, as a publicly listed

BREAK.PARA: company, want to be losing business to overseas exchanges or to competing exchanges in this country.

Some people may have said that there are no foreign ownership controls but the government has covered that by pointing out that no individual would be able to own more than 5 per cent of the Australian Stock Exchange as a publicly listed company. This is balanced legislation which prepares the Australian Stock Exchange for the next century. It is legislation which is strongly supported by the current members of the Australian Stock Exchange, and it is legislation that is backed by both sides of the parliament. It is good, sound legislation and I am very pleased that it will be receiving the overwhelming support of this chamber. I commend the bill to the committee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Anthony, Larry, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support the government on the Corporations Law Amendment (ASX) Bill and join with the previous speaker, the honourable member for Fisher (Mr Slipper), in congratulating the House on the bipartisan approach to this quite revolutionary development that will be happening to the Australian Stock Exchange.
—Evolutionary.

—Evolutionary, as well. The main features of the draft bill are clarifying the responsibilities of the ASX as a self‐regulatory organisation and ensuring appropriate accountability of the Australian Stock Exchange to the ASC and to the government in carrying out its self‐regulatory organisational responsibilities; limiting persons and their associates, Australian and foreign, to owning or controlling no more than five per cent of the shares in the Australian Stock Exchange; and providing that the ASC supervises the ASX's compliance with its listing rules in respect of the ASX's own proposed listing.

SPEECH.PARA: But the evolution of this bill, the Corporations Law Amendment (ASX) Bill 1997 has occurred so that the nexus between the ownership of the Stock Exchange and the access to the share market will be broken. The ownership of the Australian Stock Exchange will be open to anyone who wishes to buy its shares while access to the markets will also be available.

The principal reason why Australian Stock Exchange members recommended that the government make amendments to the Corporations Law Amendment (ASX) Bill 1997 was because the financial market and the global environment that we are in have changed quite significantly and have brought new challenges to the Australian Stock Exchange. There have been structural changes, particularly with the globalisation of financial markets and cross‐border competition of listing, trading and competition within Australia.

One of the principal reasons why it needs to be demutualised is that the Australian Stock Exchange needs funds for further capital expansion. Why? Because of the increasing competition of globalisation and the necessity to have new technology and communication. Likewise, in the past where governments have been barriers of control, they are no longer, particularly when it comes to exchange rates or to the flow of capital, so further assistance is needed to the ASX particularly to raise capital.

Institutional investors can also move money anywhere and cross‐border activities amount to over $6 trillion. Therefore it is essential that we hold on to our local companies and we need a more flexible approach while attracting foreign companies to have either listings or joint listings on the Australian Stock Exchange.

With the advent of new technology, more sophisticated computer hardware and software will be needed to meet the challenges in the future. In the last decade the Australian Stock Exchange spent over $120 million. The funding for this came from the Securities Institute Development Account, SIDA, and the National Guarantee Fund, NGF.

BREAK.PARA: However, in this new environment of low interest rates and the requirements for higher margin calls and deposits and with the advent of more sophisticated derivatives—and of course there is added competition now with the Australian Stock Exchange against the SFE—higher surplus funds will no longer be as available as they have been in the past for expanding new technologies that are necessary to maintain our competitive edge and indeed to increase it, particularly to North Asia.

Therefore, the Australian Stock Exchange must generate more of its own funds to replace existing hardware and software systems. The bottom line that was principally behind this key decision to demutualise was to raise further finance. Thus the Corporations Law needed to be amended because the corporations laws at present do not permit a company limited by guarantee to change its structure to a company limited by shares, which is exactly the status for all other companies listed on the Australian Stock Exchange. That came from the ASE research information paper.

Members should also understand that the Australian Stock Exchange is the central facilitator for Australian capital markets and provides a vital role in the allocation of savings of Australians to productive capital investment. Clearly this is what was demonstrated recently with the listing of Telstra.

One of the other driving forces behind the demutualisation decision was that the Australian Stock Exchange has a very unusual balance sheet and over 80 per cent of the financial assets are in cash. Quite frankly this is not an appropriate structure for the future for this type of organisation as it competes against other global exchanges to attract capital—although the Australian Stock Exchange has had a tremendous track record to date.

Certainly, looking back over the past 10 years, in the market capitalisation of early 1986‐87 when I worked in the equities market myself, domestic equities were $184 billion. That figure today has gone to over $444 billion in domestic equities or market capitalisation. When you include the overseas equities in 1986‐87, which was a very small $42 billion, that figure has now gone to $290 billion. In total, we have seen a rise in market capitalisation from the mid‐1980s from $226 billion to over $734 billion.

That is a great credit to the Australian Stock Exchange. An interesting factor, though, is that the actual number of listed companies has decreased from the early 1986‐87 figure of 1,320 to just under 1,200 today. We have seen huge numbers of mergers and takeovers—and, obviously, companies that have not complied to ASX have been delisted—and we have seen a far more transparent and fair regulatory environment, which was very different to the 1980s, where the corporate cowboys were evident wherever you looked.

In actual equity raising, there has been a massive increase in equity raising this year of over $16 billion. We have seen record turnovers and record participation of Australians in equity ownership: from 22 per cent, as mentioned by the previous speaker, up to 36 per cent indirectly—which is very different from where Australia was at 10 or even 15 years ago. At the current rate, we could well surpass the United States, particularly, which has one of the highest equity participation ratios.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is almost certain.

—Certainly, with the demutualisation of the AMP, this will happen. The purpose of the bill is to enable the conversion of the Australian Stock Exchange to a public company. The Australian Stock Exchange, as mentioned, is presently a company limited by guarantee and, therefore, the liability of its members is limited to the respective amounts that the members undertake to contribute to the property of the company if it is wound up. This really is obsolete in this age. Contrast this with companies limited by shares, with the liability of members being limited to any amount which is unpaid on their shares.

BREAK.PARA: Each member currently in the Australian Stock Exchange has an equal interest in the company; therefore it is termed a mutual organisation. That is why it is being demutualised. This decision was reached on 22 October 1996, where the members of the Australian Stock Exchange voted 540 to 22 to demutualise—which was quite extraordinary, because they actually had tried to do this a number of times in the past, but were not able to reach the magical 75 per cent of membership approval. Thus the ASX will be converting from a company limited by guarantee to a company limited by shares.

As I mentioned before, the Australian Stock Exchange plays a vital role in facilitating the trading of securities in listed companies and performs a regulatory role through the use of its listing rules and its ultimate power to delist a company. Certainly, there have been concerns that the Australian Securities Commission may eventually absorb most of ASX's regulatory functions. We will have to wait and see. Indications are at this stage that most of those functions will remain with the Australian Stock Exchange—with, of course, the exemption of its own listing.

The main provisions in the bill, in proposed sections 766E to 766I, have the effect of prohibiting any person from being entitled to more than five per cent of the voting shares in the Australian Stock Exchange. There has been much debate over why the Australian Stock Exchange has such a low limit, particularly when compared with foreign companies, who are limited at 15 per cent; with banks, at 10 per cent; and indeed with casinos, which have to have regulatory approval to go above five per cent.

I believe there is very strong justification—even though it might fly in the face of having an availability to move up to higher holdings in capital markets—for it to be essential that the ASX has a very broad diversity of ownership so that no particular institution can gain control of the ASX, which is obviously one of the main facilitators for capital in Australia. And it is in the public interest that no individual person gain control of the ASX. So there are very good reasons why the government has decided to limit the level to five per cent, and I am encouraged to see that the opposition also endorses that.

The other principal reason, of course, is that it becomes more liquid. This is particularly important. We certainly do not want to see foreign companies having any further control, particularly in an environment where it is very competitive amongst the New York Stock Exchange, Tokyo, London, or, of course, the new developing markets in Asia.

The other proposed section is 769A to 769D, and they are concerned with the Australian Stock Exchange ensuring that each stock market of the exchange is an orderly and fair market and that there are adequate arrangements for monitoring and enforcing compliance.

Part of this comes down to the actual administrative and voting structure of the new demutualised stock exchange. There will not be a requirement, as there has been in the past, for decisions to be made where there has to be 75 per cent in favour of a decision. It was very difficult to reach that, because the ownership to date has been by stockbrokers.

What will happen now with regard to the decision making ability of the Australian Stock Exchange after demutualisation is that there will be a board that will be principally making those decisions. Those decisions can be made more rapidly and be more relevant to what is happening with public companies today.

As you look towards the future of the Australian Stock Exchange, it has had a tremendous growth rate. We have managed to obtain enormous amounts of capital internally through a number of public listings such as Telstra. This has seen a rapid increase in share ownership across Australia; we have also seen the demutualisation of other organisations, particularly Colonial, National Mutual and, of course, the big one, AMP, which will be, potentially, quite revolutionary: over another million shareholders could enter the market.

By demutualising and becoming more modern, the Australian Stock Exchange will have an ability to raise capital, because it has a limited balance sheet now. Its balance sheet can become more flexible, and decision making can be made more appropriately. We can maintain our competitive edge, but, more importantly, be a beacon to continue to attract foreign listings onto the Australian Stock Exchange to develop new and more sophisticated derivatives markets—for which the ASX have been leaders, along with the Sydney Futures Exchange—and, likewise, capitalise on the uncertainty that is happening now to our northern neighbours in South‐East Asia and also to north Asia.

With a number of scandals that have been happening for many years now in Japan—one of their largest security houses, Yamaichi, potentially going into liquidation—with their banking system, there is a great advantage for Australia, for the Australian Securities Exchange, and for financial markets to stake out a much bigger claim in Asia. There is also the benefit of the time zone that we are in and our transparency. The other advantages we have are a very sophisticated IT industry and a transparent financial system and these can be used to the advantage of the Australian Securities Exchange.

In conclusion, I endorse the move to have the Corporations Law Amendment Bill amended to take into account the demutualisation of the Australian Stock Exchange. It has done a terrific job—so has the chairman, I might add, Maurice Newman—and I do believe that the next decade will be an exciting decade. We are leading the way for this demutualisation. There have been other exchanges which have not gone to full demutualisation, for example Stockholm, and there are three other exchanges in Europe.

This is a new frontier amongst capital markets, but if we lead the way then there are other markets and other availabilities that we might be able to trade on.I congratulate ASX and also the House for its bipartisan support of this bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Miles, Chris, MP

TALKER.NAME: Mr MILES
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary [Cabinet] to the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply—I would just like to thank those people who have participated in the debate. As the member for Richmond (Mr Anthony) has said, it has been a bipartisan debate in regard to support for this going ahead with the changes with the Australian Stock Exchange.

SPEECH.PARA: There are a few comments which I would like to make. First of all, the member for Wills (Mr Kelvin Thomson), the only member who spoke from the opposition, quoted some figures in regard to the Australian Stock Exchange annual report, claiming that there have been large falls in the Australian Stock Exchange funding. What I can say to you—I cannot give you the exact figures—is that the figures quoted in the Australian Stock Exchange annual report for the Australian securities budget are incorrect. I just want to put that on the record. While there has been some reduction in the funding of the ASC, it is nowhere near the reduction quoted in the ASX's annual report.

The government is confident that the ASC will be able to make the necessary efficiencies to continue to meet its regulatory functions and responsibilities within the reduced budget. The member for Wills also made comments relating to the issue of public confidence in the Australian stock exchange in the context of allegations that different shareholders may be treated differently in the allocation of shares in popular floats.

It would be inappropriate to discuss specifically the circumstances of particular allegations made today. Those are matters for the ASC as the independent statutory regulator of the markets. Let me say that I think there is a constant theme from some people in the opposition to play personality politics rather than policy politics, and this was a classic example of that here today. It is just personality politics rather than a case of getting on with the debate of the issue at hand.

I will however make a number of general points in reply. The bill will impose a specific obligation on the Australian Stock Exchange in paragraph 769A(i)(c) to have adequate arrangements for the expulsion, supervision and the disciplining of a member for conduct inconsistent with just and equitable principles in the transaction of business. The bill is also concerned that the co‐regulatory arrangements of the ASX and the ASC continue to ensure the appropriate regulation of the market and the activities of participants in that market.

The amendments proposed to be made to the Corporations Law will impose on the ASX specific obligations to conduct a fair and orderly market. The operations of the ASX and its market will, as of now, be oversighted in the first instance by the ASC under the memorandum of understanding moved by the ASC and the ASX.

The memorandum of understanding deals with three or four points. Firstly, with reference to the membership and the oversight of brokers, this MOU sets out agreed arrangements for promoting cooperation in monitoring, surveillance and enforcement action in relation to ASX members. It details procedures that the ASX will undertake in its surveillance of ASX members, and provides for the referral of serious matters concerning the conduct of ASX members to the ASC.

Secondly, with regard to market trading and referrals, this MOU provides for the referral of serious matters by the ASX to the ASC. Serious matters include: market manipulation, insider trading, and warehousing.

Thirdly, it deals with the surveillance and monitoring of compliance by listed companies with the disclosure, accounting and corporate governance requirements of the ASX listing rules, and certain parts of the Corporations Law. In the event that the ASC were to have concerns with the operations of the ASX and its market, it would furnish appropriate advice to the minister. The minister will have the power to issue a directive to the ASX requiring it to do specified things that the minister believes will promote compliance by the ASX with the ongoing obligations imposed on it. If the ASX failed to comply with that directive, the ASC may apply to the court for an order that the ASX does so comply.

In the light of these arrangements—as a rebuttal to the comments made by the member for Wills in that area—the government does not thus anticipate any fall in public confidence in the operations of the Australian Stock Exchange, and we are totally confident that these arrangements are satisfactory. Once again I thank all of those people who participated in the debate and I commend the bill to the House.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —If no member wishes to consider the bill in detail, I will put the report question forthwith. The question is that this bill be reported to the House without amendment.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: White Paper on Foreign and Trade Policy

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 20 November, on motion by Mr Downer:
That the House take note of the paper.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Willis, Ralph, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I welcome the opportunity to make some comments on this important white paper some three months after the document was brought into the parliament with the announcement that this represented the coming of age of our foreign policy. All I can say is that it has taken an awfully long time for its coming before the parliament, although it was, I admit, discussed last week in this committee.

SPEECH.PARA: At the outset can I say that the background against which this paper was produced and commissioned was a raft of policy bungles that have upset our neighbours and trading partners, and that such a paper was necessary to try to give some appearance of coherence and direction to our foreign policy.
