I will just instance some of those policy bungles.

Soon after the government came into office we had the abolition of DIFF, the Development Import Finance Facility, which caused great upset to a number of our trading partners in Asia, especially China, Indonesia and the Philippines, particularly through the way it was handled. Then we caused further upset to China by the government's portrayal of the annual Ausmin security talks with the United States last year as a `reinvigoration' of the alliance. China interpreted that as the alliance being directed against it, so souring its relations with Australia and the United States.

Then there was major concern created in Asian countries by the racist statement to the House last September by the member for Oxley (Ms Hanson). Of course, the government was not to blame for that, but it was very much to blame for the fact that it was not until eight months later that the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) repudiated, in unambiguous terms, those remarks. The fact that there was that delay caused deep scars in our relationship with Asian countries. In particular, the whole incident has reawakened Asian stereotype thinking about Australia as a white supremacy, racist nation—a notion of Australia that we had, with much success, been endeavouring to bury over the last 25 years. Nothing this government has done has been more damaging to Australia than its eight months of wilful silence on this most important issue.

Then we had the issue in the United Nations last October where we were humiliated by a defeat by Portugal for a seat on the Security Council. Of course, the factors I have just been referring to were not unimportant in that outcome. Then, just a few months ago, we had the appalling incident at the South Pacific finance ministers meeting in Cairns, with the careless handling of an extraordinarily graphic, no holds barred, background briefing on South Pacific nations and their leaders. Its subsequent reporting in the press created a major embarrassment and caused deep offence to our South Pacific neighbours, which was made much worse by the refusal of the Treasurer (Mr Costello) to apologise. Altogether, this was one of the most gauche episodes in Australian diplomatic history.

BREAK.PARA: Then, in October, we again alienated our South Pacific neighbours at the South Pacific Forum conference in the Cook Islands, at which Australia's uncompromising position on greenhouse gases had us apparently isolated 15 to 1. Not even New Zealand was reported as supporting us. Certainly, the greenhouse gas issue is a difficult issue for Australia, but not just for us. Faced with nations which would be drowned by a couple of metres rise in the sea level, we appeared unsympathetic and self‐interested. Altogether, our relations with our South Pacific neighbours must now be at about as low an ebb as at any time since Queenslanders were kidnapping South Pacific islanders to work as slaves in their canefields.

Furthermore, we also have the current issue before the parliament of the Native Title Act, with the appearance of us engaging in action which is a breach of our own Racial Discrimination Act in taking a racist position, an action which is being noted overseas and again embarrassing us on the international scene.

A good indication of how Australia stands in international circles was provided by the recent comments of a leading international figure—himself an Australian, born and bred—Jim Wolfensohn, the President of the World Bank. He praised Australia for its reaching out to Asia through its leadership in APEC, the ASEAN consultative group and the work we did in Cambodia—all, of course, Labor initiatives. But then he went on to express his concerns about Australia's current leadership and whether it had the courage and belief to lead Australia to take advantage of the great opportunities provided by its geography and innate capacities.

This is the context in which the white paper has to be seen, a context of extraordinary blunders and serious policy mistakes and the international perception of a government that is unsure about Asia and lacking in courage and belief to be fully involved with it. This white paper is clearly an attempt to put some coherence and substance into what had become a policy shambles. The best one can say for it is that it was sorely needed, but it will require much more than this pedestrian document to restore Australia's international standing.

The document is called In the national interest: Australia's foreign and trade policy which begs the question: what is the national interest? The document answers that question in this way. On page (iii), it says:

Preparing for the future is a not matter of grand constructs. It is about the hard‐headed pursuit of the interests which lie at the core of foreign and trade policy: the security of the Australian nation and the jobs and standard of living of the Australian people.

That was a definition of the security of the national interests. There is no argument that ensuring national security and enhancing employment and living standards should be key objectives for our foreign affairs and trade policy. However, the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Downer) went so far as to say that this was the jobs foreign and trade policy. If he wants to call it the jobs policy and have it measured on that basis, he has got an appalling problem, because the jobs record of this government, compared with that of the previous government, is quite appalling.

Perhaps more importantly in this context, in the definition of the national interests, it seems extraordinarily insular to say that these factors of national security, employment and living standards are the only factors that comprise our national interests. What about our obligations to be a good international citizen? To be concerned about such matters as world health problems, world environmental problems, the international drug trade, the poverty of three billion people living on $2 per day or less, the need to promote human rights around the world, the need to promote the rights of women, children, indigenous populations et cetera: are these not matters that concern the national interest?

Certainly, the narrow and, one could say, selfish approach of the white paper forms an interesting contrast with the policy declarations of the previous Labor government, which were spelt out in very substantial terms in the book Australia's Foreign Relations by the previous Foreign Minister Mr Gareth Evans and Mr Bruce Grant, in which the third leg of being a good international citizen was given great prominence.

It also makes an interesting comparison to look at the new Labor government in Britain and the way in which it defines its role. They issued a mission statement by Robin Cook, the Foreign Secretary, on 12 May, soon after coming into office. And this is how it read at the start:
The Mission of the Foreign and Commonwealth Office is to promote the national interests of the United Kingdom and to contribute to a strong world community.
We shall pursue that Mission to secure for Britain four benefits through our policy:
Then they go on to security and prosperity. Under the heading, `Quality of Life', it says:
We shall work with others to protect the World's environment and to counter the menace of drugs, terrorism and crime;
Under `Mutual Respect' it says:
We shall work through international forms and bilateral relationships to spread the values of human rights, civil liberties and democracy which we demand for ourselves.

So they put these other issues of being good international citizens right up there, up front with the other issues of security and prosperity for the British people. The contrast with this white paper is quite marked.

The paper does go on to discuss some national values briefly, in a low‐key secondary way, and in that regard it does give a quite unambiguous rejection of racial discrimination and commitment to racial equality, and that was very welcome. Indeed, it should have been said straight after the speech of the member for Oxley in September of last year.

Apart from racial equality, no other human right is specifically mentioned. The paper heavily emphasises the need for a pragmatic approach to promoting human rights. Perhaps we are seeing what this pragmatic approach means in operation in China where, after we had alienated China, as I mentioned earlier, we then sought to get back into China's good books by refusing to support a resolution condemning China's human rights abuses at the UN human rights convention earlier this year, a resolution traditionally supported by Australia.

When the Prime Minister visited China, discussion on human rights was hived off for secret talks between officials. As far as I am aware, there is no public indication of the nature and extent of those discussions, except for a report in the Financial Review of 28 August of this year, in an article by Paul Monk headed, `Beijing's deadly secrets'. In talking about these secret discussions, he said:

Since the dialogue is to be secret, it is hard to know what its terms of reference are to be. We may gather something of its character, however, from the fact that the Chinese Government has announced that political prisoners are not under discussion, because of course, "China does not have any political prisoners".
If that is an indication of the nature of these discussions, we cannot expect too much to be coming from them. In other words, it would be a very pragmatic approach to human rights indeed.

In relation to the economy, the white paper places great stress on the importance of opening up our economy to international markets and to economic integration with Asia, and it is absolutely right to do that. The Minister for Foreign Affairs correctly points to the extraordinary development in our economic links with the Asia‐Pacific region in the last 15 years or so, but he fails to say that this has happened mostly as a result of the previous Labor government's initiatives. I refer to such things as the development of a much more competitive economy; the major reductions in tariffs set in place under Labor; the establishment of APEC, which was a Labor idea; the APEC leaders conference, which was the idea of Prime Minister Paul Keating; and the Bogor declaration, which Labor was instrumental in initiating and which sets the scene for further tariff reductions throughout the region. All of these initiatives endorsed by the white paper are very much Labor initiatives.

The white paper essentially commits to processes started by Labor: the continuance of APEC and the pursuance of the Bogor declaration to bring that to fruition. It notes that Australia has already reduced tariffs and other barriers more than most other APEC member countries—something which Labor put in place. As for the future, it states that the government will take account of what other governments are doing in deciding future steps. That is a position that Labor articulated well before the government adopted that policy approach.

Finally, the white paper's assessment regarding the most profound influences on Australia's foreign and trade policies over the next 15 years refers to globalisation and the continuing economic rise of East Asia. It states on page v at paragraph 17:
The Government's judgment is that economic growth in industrialising East Asia will continue at relatively high levels over the next fifteen years.
That may well be right as a long‐term judgment, but in the short‐ to medium‐term it appears increasingly like a wrong call.

Even before the white paper was published, events were occurring in Asia which might have led to some caution, but since then the unfolding array of crashes in currency markets, stock markets, property markets and financial institutions in East Asia have increasingly undermined the white paper's assessment. At least in the short term, for the next one or two years, East Asian growth is certainly going to be considerably reduced by all these aspects. It will vary between the countries, but certainly in Thailand, South Korea and probably Indonesia, growth is going to be drastically reduced, if not put into recession, and certainly growth in other countries will be significantly impaired.

In the light of all that, one would have to conclude that this is a potentially very serious development. President Clinton, at the APEC leaders meeting currently occurring in Vancouver said that we now have a global crisis. Given that East Asia accounted for 40 per cent of world economic growth in 1996, a dramatic slowing in the growth of this region—which now appears certain—must impact upon the whole world.

With 60 per cent of Australia's exports in the region, we must expect that they will be substantially affected, with both reduced volumes and prices. But in addition, we must expect a flood of imports from East Asian countries whose prices will now be much more competitive in Australian dollars. And as their domestic economies languish, there will be great pressure on them to expand exports to obtain some form of economic growth. So for us that means rapidly rising imports, great pressure on our import competing industries and a substantially deteriorating current account.

It also means reduced growth. The Treasurer said that it would be barely measurable, but the OECD has already said that the GDP growth reduction for Australia would be about 0.4 per cent in 1998 and that in other countries it would be up to about three‐quarters of a per cent—and all that was before South Korea was in the hands of the IMF.

So for the next couple of years—hopefully no longer than that—our extensive integration with East Asia is likely to mean that we will wear some substantial economic pain, more so than most other developed Western countries which are not so integrated. It would be a great tragedy, however, if that led us to go back on our commitment to trade liberalisation. This is a short‐term issue for us. We should not let it distract us from the long‐term benefits of trade liberalisation. We should keep our eyes on the longer gain, and there will be long‐term benefits as East Asia gets back on its growth path. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Slipper, Peter, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I am very pleased to participate in the debate whereby the committee will note the white paper In the national interest: Australia's foreign and trade policy , published recently by the government. It is a visionary document and a document which should enjoy bipartisan support. Foreign policy in Australia has been a bipartisan matter, largely, and it is rather sad to see the honourable member for Gellibrand (Mr Willis) descending into a party political debate on what really ought to be a bipartisan approach to our national and foreign policy white paper.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not know whether the member saw the Australian yesterday in which the opposition foreign affairs spokesman, the honourable member for Kingsford‐Smith (Mr Brereton), is quoted as deriding the performance of the Keating government. The article said:

In an extraordinary attack on his colleagues, Mr Brereton accused the former government of badly misjudging community feeling on French nuclear testing in the South Pacific during 1995 and putting obstacles in the way of a landmines ban rather than trying to find a solution.

TALK.START.PARA: —That's refreshing honesty.

—Unfortunately, the honourable member for Kingsford‐Smith is not always known for that. However, he did point out that there was evidence of foreign policy fatigue during Labor's last months in government. It is obvious that was one of the reasons why the Labor Party was cast from office in March last year.

SPEECH.PARA: Returning to this particular white paper on foreign and trade policy, it gives that policy a very sharp focus and it represents a coming of age of Australian foreign policy. I believe it is very important to recognise the white paper stresses that Australia's national interest will drive our approach in foreign and trade policy. In other words, we will make no apology whatsoever in international fora and elsewhere for standing up for what we believe is in the interest of this nation.

I believe the courageous stand taken by the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) in relation to greenhouse emissions is another indication that this government is prepared to stand up and be counted for Australian jobs. The government's approach to greenhouse, particularly given the statement made by the Prime Minister last week, is fair and balanced and reasonable, and I believe that all of us ought to support it 100 per cent.

Our approach to foreign and trade policy will aim to improve the security, the jobs and the standard of living of all Australians. It will do this in a number of ways. Firstly, there is a clear recognition that Australia has global interests which require an active trade and foreign policy of broad scope. We believe that since we are in the Asia-Pacific region the Asia-Pacific region should be our first and highest priority, although not our only priority. The white paper is a public declaration, in effect, of our commitment to the Asia-Pacific region.

It is vital to realise that our policy may be Asia first but it is not Asia only. Australia does have interests in other parts of the world and the white paper recognises that our interests are not limited to any one region, although it stresses the very important role that our relationship with the Asia-Pacific region will play in the future.

I must say that there is a great misconception in the Australian community over the benefits of trade liberalisation. Many people say to me that the reduction in tariffs means that we are costing Australian their jobs and that we are casting Australian families out of the work force. I believe that view is quite inappropriate.

I am heartened by the bipartisan approach, largely, to trade liberalisation that exists between this government and its predecessor. It is always important to recognise that trade liberalisation has very many benefits for the Australian economy and for Australians. As a country which exports many products, we benefit more from trade liberalisation than some other countries do. Unfortunately, it must be noted that there are some short-term adjustment costs but even conservative estimates point out that the average Australian family has gained $1,000 per year from tariff reductions.

A recent publication pointed out that families now have access to a wider range of affordable and high quality products, that imported cars would cost 25 per cent more if the 1988 tariffs still applied—which is an extra $5,000 to $20,000 a car—and that clothing and footwear would cost around 14 per cent more, which is an extra $300 or so, per year, for the average family to maintain its dress standards. It also pointed out that falls in trade barriers have contributed to a stronger industrial base, higher productivity, better access to international markets and new technologies and more competitive manufactured and services exports.

While unfortunately some factories have closed, improved processing by other manufacturers, education, tourism and other services have produced good news. As other countries join us in trade liberalisation, there will be increased opportunities for Australian products and, as a result, we will create Australian jobs and our economy will be boosted. This is a policy that the former Labor government and this government have both supported.

We ought not resile from the fact that we are in favour of trade liberalisation. The pauses in the areas of the motor vehicle and textile, clothing and footwear indistries that have occurred will create some increased investment but the overall policy is that tariffs should, must and will reduce because it is in the interests of Australia that this should happen. The former Labor government, to an extent, was sidetracked into indulging too much in multilateral international arrangements. We are certainly not opposed to multilateral arrangements but we believe there are very great advantages to Australia through bilateral arrangements whereby we are able to come to individual arrangements with individual countries to make decisions which are in Australia's national interests. In supporting the principle of bilateral relationships, we are not undermining the necessity for Australia to take its role in multilateral fora but the balance has changed with the change in government.

The focus of our bilateral trade and investment efforts is very much on tailored and customised strategies. This means that different markets will need different levels of government support for Australian exporting and investors. I believe this is a very important change. Although the foreign policy of Australia does not automatically change with an alteration in government, and it has been largely bipartisan, this new emphasis on the importance of bilateral strategies is certainly an improvement which will work to Australia's interest.

Over the next 15 years, our bilateral strategies will emphasise domestic regulatory elements and services. This will require Australia's trade negotiators to have a greater specialisation and expertise in areas such as barriers to services trade, intellectual property, investment impediments and anticompetitive behaviour by firms. This focus will be critical for Australia to capture its share of the high value‐added activity in the international chain of production. We saw the Prime Minister play a key role in the recent APEC forum, and bilateral and regional fora will continue to provide means for pursuing bilateral objectives.

The honourable member for Gellibrand mentioned certain comments made by the honourable member for Oxley (Ms Hanson) in September 1996. I place on record my very grave concern at the impact that the comments made by the honourable member for Oxley are having in relation to our trade with South‐East Asia. I have been to South‐East Asia on a number of occasions and I have seen newspapers report those comments in a way that indicates that this nation is racist. I think most people in the chamber and most Australians would agree that we are one of the most tolerant countries in the world. The newspapers abroad, I believe, have done the wrong thing in so far as they have claimed that we are biased against people on the basis of race. That is clearly not the case.

The simple fact of the matter is that newspapers in South‐East Asia are read by people in the same way as newspapers here. The net result is that there could be some adverse impact on our exports to Asia. That would be tragic because Australia is very well located to export many things to South‐East Asia, particular primary products, and the government's supermarket to Asia program is outstanding. We export an enormous percentage of Singapore's consumption of dairy products. One can go to many of the stores in Singapore and see Australian products everywhere on the shelves.

TALK.START.PARA: —You've been to Tanglin market as well, haven't you?

—Indeed. I think that what we have to do as a nation is make sure that we emphasise that we are a tolerant nation. We should point out to them the reality of the situation. It is eminently regrettable, firstly, that the honourable member for Oxley's comments have been reported in this way and, secondly, that she has made some of those comments at all.

SPEECH.PARA: Returning to this white paper, it is a very forward thinking document. It is a statement of commitment to the Asia‐Pacific region. I believe that it will be supported by the Australian people and, ultimately, by the Labor Party as well. Happily, foreign policy is largely a matter of bipartisan approach by both parties in the parliament. It is absolutely essential that we recognise we are all about Asia first, but not Asia only. This country will benefit greatly as it seeks to work as part of the Asia‐Pacific region, but there are also opportunities in other parts of the world. The white paper certainly recognises that those opportunities are there.

I would like to congratulate the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Downer) and the Minister for Trade (Mr Tim Fischer) on producing such a forward thinking document. The government ought to be commended for stating where we stand so clearly and so unequivocally. I believe that it is tragic that the honourable member for Gellibrand came into the committee today and sought to denigrate the wonderful job that this government has done in the area of foreign affairs. The honourable member for Throsby laughs. The honourable member for Kingsford‐Smith yesterday said that the Labor Party suffered from foreign policy fatigue.

TALK.START.PARA: —At least he had the courage to come out and say it.

—He did, and of course that courage has not always manifested itself in the honourable member for Kingsford‐Smith, but in doing so he condemned the honourable member for Holt (Mr Gareth Evans) and also Senator Ray. I would have liked very much to have been a fly on the wall when they reacted to the comments made by the honourable member for Kingsford‐Smith.
—I think your ears would be too delicate.
—They may well have been too delicate—

TALKER.NAME: Madam DEPUTY SPEAKER (Hon. J. A. Crosio)

TALK.START.PARA: —The member for Fisher has the floor; he does not need interjection to assist him in the debate.

—Thank you, Madam Deputy Speaker. It would have been very interesting to know what the response of those two gentlemen was to that interesting attack by the honourable member for Kingsford‐Smith. I suppose that they were not at all happy with him. This is a very important document; it is a positive document; it is an outstanding document. It states where the government stands, and I commend it to the chamber.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hollis, Colin, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I listened to the honourable member for Fisher (Mr Slipper). I think most people would agree that we would want a bipartisan approach on many foreign affairs issues, but that does not mean that we have to blindly follow everything that the government does. We are a different political party. We do take a different point of view on many issues. Where we can, we are happy to extend that bipartisanship in so many areas. Of course, we have the right as well to put an independent point of view on foreign policy where we see it as being appropriate.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me at the outset make it clear that I welcome this white paper on Australian foreign and trade policy. I note that the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Downer), said that the starting point of the paper is that an active foreign and trade policy is crucial to Australia's future security and prosperity. He went on to say that it is crucial because Australia has global interests and, as part of the global economy, its prosperity is tied to its performance as a trading nation.

I agree entirely with this statement. Australia does have global interests and, for this reason, I am very concerned at the downgrading, cost‐cutting and also closure of many of our diplomatic missions. I do not believe that in every country there should be an overseas mission or that every post of the overseas mission should be filled by totally Australian based staff. There is an argument for the employment of locally engaged staff, where appropriate; but I cannot understand why, if we have global interests, we are constantly cutting missions throughout the world.

We are not represented in much of Africa, as indeed we are not in Latin America. Our posts in Africa are faced with an impossible task of adequately presenting Australia's case with constantly cut resources. For example, the post in Zimbabwe represents eight or nine African countries: it is just an impossible task. The same applies in Latin America. I am not for one moment suggesting that Australia should have a diplomatic mission in every country, but we are far too thin on the ground in far too many parts of the world.

BREAK.PARA: The closure of the post in Denmark was a mistake and will be seen to be a mistake. I still cannot understand why we do not have a mission in Addis Ababa, the headquarters of the Organisation of African Unity. One parliamentary delegation went to Ethiopia and recommended that we open a mission there. When the report came down, they accepted that recommendation and we opened a mission. It was in operation for 12 months and then it closed. The Canadians walked into the premises and got everything at a very low rate.

The point that I am making about Addis Ababa is that it is the headquarters of the Organisation of African Unity and, if for no other reason than as a contact point or a listening point, I believe that the mission there should be reopened. There was much soul‐searching and wringing of hands when Australia missed out last year on a position on the United Nations Security Council. Might I suggest that it was our lack of representation in Africa, especially francophone Africa, that contributed in part to our not achieving that position? The largest block of votes in the UN is the African nations. We have got a couple of missions in Africa and not one single post in francophone Africa.

I am also concerned about the direction Australia is taking with regard to overseas aid, especially in relation to population programs. Australia's aid level today rates as 13th out of 21 in OECD countries. This is a drop from ninth in the previous year, and so Australia's aid ratio is falling. Australia has a responsibility to support the continuation of assistance for family planning programs, especially as part of an overall health strategy. Although the question of human rights is often difficult—and the honourable member for Aston (Mr Nugent) appreciates that it is a difficult situation—I do believe that we gain respect by speaking out on human rights issues. Having said that, it is important that our own human rights situation be beyond reproach.

I am concerned that, on so many issues, Australia appears to be reneging on the strong commitment we had on these issues. The refusal regarding the human rights clause in the European Community treaty last year was ridiculous. We sent all the wrong messages about human rights and reinforced all the wrong prejudices that other countries have about us, in that we are prepared to pontificate, especially on human rights, yet we will not subject ourselves to the scrutiny we demand and expect of others.

The cutting of funding to international bodies, such as the United Nations agencies, especially in relation to population programs, the cut in our funding to the International Planned Parenthood Federation, and the cuts in the funding to the United Nations Fund on Population and Development are not worthy of Australia. In an overall budgetary context, it did not amount to a lot of money. To the organisations concerned, not only was it a severe cut but, again, it sent all the wrong, negative messages.

The honourable member for Fisher said that there should be a bipartisan approach to foreign policy issues. We on this side will not agree to sending all those wrong, negative messages, especially in relation to population issues and many, many other issues, and there is no way that we are going to support the government in what they are doing here. We are going to criticise them and raise the issues constantly so that hopefully in the next budget this funding will be restored.

The same wrong message is being sent to the world regarding greenhouse gas emissions. I do not want to quote the honourable member for Fisher too much, but nevertheless during his speech, which I listened to with great interest, he did say that the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) did make a courageous statement on greenhouse gas emissions. The definition of `courageous' is open to interpretation. I actually do not think it was a terribly courageous statement—when you are in a minority, when you are offside with most of the world.

Now, again, greenhouse is a difficult issue and it is difficult for Australia. I represent a coalmining area; I know the issues involved in greenhouse. I am not saying for one moment that it is an easy issue—it is a difficult issue—but I do think that the message that we are sending from Australia on greenhouse gas emissions is a wrong message.

The Prime Minister makes much of the fact that he is saving jobs, especially in coal areas such as my own. Yet I have spoken to the miners in my area. Indeed a recent statement by John Maitland from the federation indicates that they do not support the Prime Minister's stand regarding greenhouse. Again, as I said before, we are sending a wrong and very negative message. For a government that wants to create a favourable image, we are certainly not going about it the correct way.

As I am in areas critical of the government, let me make it clear that in one area I totally support the government and the action, and that is their decision on landmines. I have long opposed these dreadful destructive weapons, and indeed was critical of my side of parliament. I do not think we moved quickly enough on landmines when we were in government. When we were in power, my objection to landmines was equally strong, so I congratulate the government for moving quickly and decisively in this area.

Managing foreign and trade policy is a challenge but governments are elected to meet these challenges. I do not think the government has shown the necessary leadership in this area and I believe that our image as a nation has been diminished by many of the stands that have been taken over recent months in the foreign policy area.

I want to turn briefly to the comments made by the honourable member for Oxley (Ms Hanson) in this debate about this time last week. I do not usually comment—I am not in the habit of commenting—on the utterances of the honourable member for Oxley as it only gives them some status. But her comments in this debate were so far over the top that they actually deserve some comment. Much as she may wish, Australia cannot divorce itself from the rest of the world. We live in an interdependent world. We have enough people arguing about internationalist conspiracy theories or pushing internationalist conspiracy theories without members of parliament peddling this trash.

It always fascinates me when people talk about tourists coming to Australia on a foreign plane and on a national carrier and prepaying their accommodation. The member for Oxley quoted this. I personally do not know if the member for Oxley has ever been overseas, but, as good a patriotic Australian as she is, I suspect that, like me, if she went overseas, she would travel on our national carrier, Qantas. I guess she would pay for her fare in Australian dollars, in Australia, to Qantas—as Japanese tourists often pay and fly on their Japanese line and people from other countries fly on their national lines. When one goes overseas, one often pays for one's accommodation before one goes. I do. Sometimes, people even pay for side trips before they go. When I do that, I pay in Australia in Australian dollars.

I do not see why people are so concerned if the Japanese—or the Italians, the Thais or whoever they are—fly on their national carrier and have prepaid their accommodation. We do it. Maybe they have paid in Thailand or Japan for a trip to the Blue Mountains, but if we want to go from Tokyo to somewhere else we pay in Australia, if we so want, to do that.

This is a furphy that is pushed, about all these people flying on their national carrier. Why shouldn't they fly on their national carrier? I am always proud to fly Qantas. If I have a choice of what airline I am going to fly on, I always fly Qantas. And, where appropriate, I prepay. You can often get a very good deal by prepaying your accommodation. So I do not know why people keep talking about this.

Other members have talked about the damage that has been done to Australia's image. I am old enough to remember the image Australia had on the White Australia policy. It took us 30 years after that policy was changed—and, I will say before people interject, by the side of parliament opposite—to live that down. So many times when you went to Asia, or to Europe and places like that, people would still raise the White Australia policy with you. We suffered unnecessarily for that for many years.

I honestly believe that we are going to suffer from the messages that the honourable member for Oxley is sending out. We are going to suffer for a long time, not only in the image of Australia we are trying to portray, but also from a financial point of view.

The honourable member for Oxley made much of jobs—youth unemployment and loss of jobs in Australia. We all deplore the lack of employment and we all, on both sides, hope that we can make a contribution to restore that. But I would say something in all sincerity to the honourable member for Oxley. While we all can be critical—no‐one is saying that the honourable member for Oxley cannot stand up in this parliament and be critical of parliament or of our government and so on; no‐one argues with that and we are all, on both sides, critical of each other—the very policies that she is advocating and the messages she is sending out will ensure the loss of jobs in Australia. They will ensure a diminution of the living standard in Australia.

That is why so many of us, on both sides of the parliament, are very critical of the comments of the honourable member for Oxley. What she says is a contradiction. She is just ensuring that what she purports to want for Australia will not be achieved. She is making a significant contribution to that. In that way, she is wrong and she should be criticised for what she is doing.

I welcome the fact that the government has put out this policy on foreign affairs and trade. It gives us in this chamber an opportunity to debate it, albeit that two or three months have been spent in the waiting list.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nugent, Peter, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday, in the House, I had the opportunity to follow the honourable member for Throsby (Mr Hollis) in a debate on a different matter, and it is coincidence that I follow him today. As usual, his is a very thoughtful and considered contribution, and I thank him for that. I do not agree with everything he said and I will challenge him on a couple of those matters, but I certainly agree with a number of the issues that he has raised.

SPEECH.PARA: Perhaps I should start by mentioning specifically his comments, and also those of the member for Fisher (Mr Slipper) who spoke before him, concerning the contribution that we have had from the member for Oxley (Ms Hanson). There is no question that if one travels around in Asia, which is an important part of the world for our country these days, Australia's response to the views of the member for Oxley will be raised.

I have had the opportunity this year to travel quite extensively, both on official delegations and in my capacity of holding office with various friendship groups. I have been to an IPO conference, I have been to Singapore and Malaysia, I have been to Hong Kong and China. Last year, I went to India and Pakistan. In talking to people in those countries, it is regrettable but still a fact that, although in formal exchanges you will not always have the subject of the views of the member for Oxley raised—it does happen on occasion—there is no doubt that in one‐to‐one conversations, 99 times out of 100, whether you are talking to MPs, Australian businessmen overseas or local business people, or people in the community, the possibility that Australia might agree in any substantive measure with the views expressed by the member for Oxley is, unfortunately, raised.

People raise it in the context: `Is it safe to invest in Australia; is it safe to send my child there to university; is it safe for my family and I to go to Australia for a holiday?' The reality of life is that if people have those concerns, and they do not have those concerns allayed, we will lose some of those people coming here for those various purposes. What that means is that the very things that the member for Oxley complains about—the loss of jobs and the loss of benefit to this country—will occur because we will not have the hotels so full, we will not have some investment in business ventures going ahead, and we will not have the education industry so well supported. And that earns us something like $2.8 billion a year; it is a very substantial industry.

There are a number of factors that will determine whether or not people invest here, come here for a holiday or send their children here for university. The reality is that it is raised so frequently in so many countries that you cannot help but feel that there has to be some negative impact. So it seems to me not only that from a moral point of view one might disagree with many of the One Nation comments, but that that party and the member for Oxley have to understand that by her utterances, which are repeated willy‐nilly, unfortunately, by the media and are often not challenged as they should be, she is actually doing this country—and by implication, therefore, her constituents—positive damage. I think that needs to be pointed out on a regular basis.

I would like to pick up a couple of the other comments from the gentleman from Throsby. He complained about the cost‐cutting in Foreign Affairs of this government; he talked about the fact that we were closing missions. I have to say that we have not actually closed very many missions. The reality of life is that a lot of it comes down to money, and his government left us a huge debt. You cannot go on racking up debt forever. Sometimes you have to take some hard decisions and you often have to take decisions that you do not like taking.

But I have to really take him to task in terms of his comments about our representation in Africa, saying that because we had closed posts in Africa we had lost the vote in the United Nations for a position on the Security Council. Frankly, that is absolute nonsense. The reality is that our lack of broad representation across the continent of Africa was something that occurred under the previous government, during their 13 years in office, and anything that we have done has frankly been peripheral and very recent in that regard.

The reason that we did not get a lot of support from African countries in that United Nations vote was very much because we did not have representation—but we had not had it for years. People reflected in that vote the view that they had built up over a long period of time, not just something that had happened in the last few months. Remember, that vote occurred within the first year or so of our being in government. So, apart from the fact that one might have the view that Mr Butler could not count anyway and would never have made a good politician because he cannot count in things like voting, the reality was that that lack of support was a result of years of our lack of representation there. It is quite inappropriate to suggest that that is something brought on by this particular government.

BREAK.PARA: But we also have to understand—and it is part of what this white paper is all about—that you cannot run foreign affairs today the way you necessarily ran it 50 years ago, or 20 years ago, or even 10 years ago. Foreign affairs, like every other field of endeavour, has to change. What the white paper is about is trying to lay down some of the basic tenets. But the way we then operate within those basic tenets will, of course, change from time to time. In business and a whole range of other fields, and also in foreign affairs, we are going to be affected, for example, by technology. We have to recognise that. It is much easier to communicate with another country, to get information. It is much easier for the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) or the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Downer) to fly off to a meeting to fix a problem.

We do not necessarily need the huge structures that we had in individual countries in yesteryear for our representation because you could not get the senior politicians there in time to deal with some of those issues. It is an entirely different ball game. For example, one of the trends that is happening—and I think a very sensible, reasonable trend that is not going to adversely affect our relationships with other countries—is that we are starting to look at and experiment with the idea of sharing representation in countries. Perhaps Australia, in one country, might represent not only our interests but also those of Canada and maybe New Zealand. In another country, there might be a reciprocal arrangement, where Canada has a post and represents us, and that sort of thing.

For example, I went to the IPO conference in Bali a few months ago. During a period when we were not actively engaged in the conference, contrary to the media perception that we might go and lie on the beach, we actually went off and looked at some of our aid projects. We visited our consul‐general in Bali to have a look at what he was doing. In Bali, he represents Australia, New Zealand, Canada and Britain. He has got a regular job with the tourist trade to Bali from all those countries, unfortunately shipping home bodies, visiting people in gaol, replacing lost passports, dealing with people who have had their money lost or whatever it is—a whole range of problems that come from having large numbers of tourists in one place. He does a very good job on behalf of Australia and three other countries.

Clearly, if we can develop reciprocal arrangements with some of those countries in other places to do the same sort of thing, we can have quite adequate representation without, in fact, having to say, `Well, we have got to have a post in every country'. But we do not lose the quality of our representation. It seems to me that multilateral representation is quite interesting.

It was interesting that the gentleman from Throsby specialised in talking about Africa. He has a special interest in Africa. Clearly, the white paper says that we have to focus on areas that are most important to us. It is not just about Asia, which is a critical area, but there are other parts of the world as well. There are parts of Africa which are of interest to us, but one has to be realistic and say that most of the continent of Africa is not at the top of our priority list. It does not mean that it is unimportant.

Like the gentleman from Throsby, I am obviously concerned about our drop in aid, as I think many of us are. Unfortunately, one has to point out though that, whilst regretting the fact that aid is dropping, it is a trend that has been there for many years. I find it, frankly, somewhat disappointing that the gentleman from Throsby, who is normally, I think, sound on these issues, really wants to make a political point about the drop in aid when, under his government for so many years, that trend was in place as well, as it is with most OECD countries.

Clearly, we are still in the top half, on a percentage basis, of aid givers in the OECD, but it is regrettable, in my view, that we are not able to get that up a bit. It seems to me that, once we get the economy moving in the right direction—and we have done a number of things in the last 19 or 20 months as a government to do that—we will have much more wealth, much more disposable income, if you like, and that is when we, hopefully, will be able to start to get the aid going in the right direction. Under the previous government, aid dropped on a regular basis and, therefore, it is nonsense to start to point the finger in this direction.

Clearly, a number of us in this parliament raise these human rights issues on a regular basis in a public way, as does the Minister for Foreign Affairs and the Prime Minister. The Prime Minister has raised a number of those issues with China, for example, and we have had open publicity about that. He has raised those issues with Indonesia. The Minister for Foreign Affairs has regularly raised those human rights issues, and he does so when he visits a whole range of countries. And there is a place to stand up and publicly raise those issues.

But equally, it has been demonstrated over the years that just to stand up and make a noise is not always effective with every country. So one of the things this government has tried to do is to adopt a new approach to human rights by saying, `If you like, we will do less head kicking with other countries in public on human rights. We will try to develop our relationships and to raise some of these things in private in the hope that, on a friendly basis, we will start to have a bit more influence in actually achieving something.'

We are only 18 or 19 months down the track of that new approach, but it seems to me that previously, although we made a lot of noise and there was a lot of rhetoric, we were not always successful in achieving the results we desired. Therefore, it is worth trying a new approach. I think it is too early; I think the jury is still out in terms of whether the new approach has been successful, but after two, three, four or five years we will obviously start to see the results. It seems to me that it is rather fruitless just to condemn a new approach without giving it time to work.

I really have to protest at the European Union comment made by the member for Throsby. He argued that we were not prepared to sign off a trade agreement because it had human rights elements linked to it. The reality of life is that not only has that matter been satisfactorily resolved to the satisfaction of Europe as well as to our satisfaction, but that in fact his government took exactly the same position when it was negotiating on exactly the same issue. So the previous government was taking no different an official position from that of the Howard government.

I am obviously pleased that the member for Throsby acknowledged the support for the position on landmines. This government was also extremely successful with things like the nuclear test ban treaty, which was a major achievement of this government.

The white paper is an important document, and it is important to recognise that it is the first time that the government—any Australian government—has laid down its foreign policy thrust. It is important that people understand where we are coming from, what our priorities are and what it is we want to do.

That does not mean that things will not change or that there may not be change to react to different circumstances as they develop. It is not to say that over a period of time there may not be some variation. But it is very helpful to have a basic understanding of where Australia is going in terms of foreign affairs, and it is very important to understand where we are going on trade policy. Of course we will have differences as time goes by; of course we will have arguments about whether you link trade to human rights and whether you do it openly or quietly.

It seems to me that the proof of the pudding is in the eating and, whilst the previous government certainly had its foreign policy successes, this government has had its foreign policy successes. Historically, we have generally followed a bipartisan foreign policy approach and I very much hope that that will continue. It seems to me that there are lot of good things in this paper which the opposition should be able to agree with, and I certainly commend the document to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Southcott, Andrew, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —In the 50 years in which Australia has had a distinctive, independent foreign policy—as the member for Aston (Mr Nugent) said—this is the first white paper which actually sets out our foreign and trade policy framework. In the evolution of Australia's foreign policy, the white paper is significant for detailing that globalisation and the rise of East Asia are likely to be the two most important influences which will affect Australia as it enters the next century. It also notes that, as the centre of gravity of the world's economy shifts from the Atlantic to the Pacific, Australia's future will lie in a successful integration in Asia.

SPEECH.PARA: As the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) has stated, this does not mean that we have to choose between our history and our geography, but rather that we must recognise that Australia faces a significant national challenge in engaging with our regional neighbours.

Paul Keating promoted the idea that he was a modern day Vasco da Gama, a modern day Marco Polo, a man who discovered the east—which his predecessors had somehow overlooked. During the last election, he promoted the idea that regional leaders would not deal with John Howard as Prime Minister. Subsequently, successful meetings with Prime Minister Mahathir, President Suharto—on two occasions—President Jiang Zemin of China and Prime Minister Hashimoto have shown that Asian leaders are comfortable dealing with Prime Minister Howard and that Keating's accusations actually ignore the fact that recognising the importance of the Asia‐Pacific over the next two decades is not the exclusive preserve of the ALP.

The importance of East Asia is not a new notion. As far back as the 1950s, Richard Casey recognised that Australia's relations with the emerging post‐colonial nations in our region would be important to our future. Initiatives such as the Colombo Plan not only assisted developing countries in Asia but changed Australia through the person to person contact they created between young Australian students and their Asian counterparts. The negotiation of the Australia‐Japan trade treaty in 1957, the abolition of the White Australia policy under Harold Holt and the recognition of China under Whitlam were all important landmarks in Australia's relations with Asia over the last 50 years.

The future for Australia in the 21st century is as a confident and open nation that accepts the challenges of competing in the international economy and the challenges of engagement in the region. On a strategic, cultural and economic level, engagement with Asia will be critical and will require foresight and flair to be successful. As the economies of ASEAN and North-East Asia continue to grow, and as the programs of military modernisation update the armed forces of East Asia, Australia will need to work hard to maintain its relative influence.

The alternative, a failure to integrate in Asia, a failure to maintain our level of influence as a medium‐level power, and retreating to a being a protected and insecure country, just does not bear contemplation. Our goal should be to be a nation in the South Pacific with European traditions, but a country that is comfortable dealing with the different cultures and languages of the Western Pacific rim, and that is able to work in a coalition of shared interests. Our expertise in Asian studies should be expanded, and many young Australians should consider improving their Asian language skills to improve our business and official links with Asia, and also our understanding of Asia.

The white paper clearly rebuts many of the myths which are being propagated by the member for Oxley (Ms Hanson) with her dangerous brand of xenophobic protectionism. The white paper shows that over the last 10 years, Australia has become a more open economy. Trade in goods and services has increased from 35 per cent of GDP to 40 per cent of GDP, and over 60 per cent of our exports are now sent to East Asia.

The white paper also demonstrates unequivocally that this increase in exports has created jobs, and that those jobs pay more. Surveys in 1995 and 1996 showed that firms which export are increasing employment faster than non‐exporters, they are more productive, and they pay better salaries. The paper also shows that since the 1950s, rural commodities have declined as a proportion of our exports as services, manufactures, and non‐rural commodities became more important. That has become particularly noticeable over the last 15 years.

As tariff protection has fallen, Australia's elaborately transformed manufactures have increased as firms' competitiveness has increased. For example, cuts in tariffs from 30 per cent in 1987 to around 5 per cent in 1996 have seen medical and scientific equipment increase their exports from $300 million in 1987 to $700 million in 1996.

It is not just Australia that is reducing its tariffs alone in a protected world. Since 1988, most East Asian nations have reduced their tariffs significantly. ASEAN nations have cut their tariffs on a trade weighted basis by about two‐thirds between 1988 and 1995.
Professor Peter Drysdale of the ANU has pointed out that 77 per cent of the increase in exports that we have seen over the last 10 years went to East Asia. To quote Professor Drysdale, he said:
Australia sends more of its growth in its exports to the countries of East Asia than does any other country in the world, including any in East Asia itself.

The recent currency and financial market turmoil which has now affected every country in East Asia has raised questions about the ability of East Asia to continue the stunning growth rates of the 1980s and 1990s. On balance, the opinion seems to be that if these nations are able to correct the weaknesses in their financial systems, maintain political stability, in the medium term manage several leadership transitions, and improve their current account deficits and the high levels of debt, then East Asia is likely to continue its high levels of growth.

Dealing with globalisation and maintaining support for policy reforms will be a significant political challenge for all governments in the next century. World trade and investment are growing much faster than the world economy. The white paper correctly identifies `that trade liberalisation and an open economy contribute to economic growth and job creation', which refutes the common notion that tariff protection actually protects jobs and reducing levels of tariffs actually leads to job losses.

Much of the growth in international trade has come in the services sector and that will continue. Services comprise about 21 per cent of world trade now and that is projected to rise to 27 per cent by the year 2010. As a consequence, critical comparative advantages for nations in the 21st century will be an openness to new technology, high levels of education and a culture of innovation.

In an article in the summer 1997 edition of Foreign Policy, Professor Dani Rodrik of Harvard University has tried to make sense of many of the myths that exist about globalisation. His thesis is that globalisation can improve a nation's overall national income but that in advanced countries this can sometimes be at the expense of a decline in wages of unskilled workers. Professor Rodrik said that `globalisation does not constrain national autonomy nearly as much as popular discussions assume.' In the paper he also highlights the significant political challenge that results from the process of globalisation.

Politicians such as Buchanan in the United States, Zhirinovsky in Russia, Le Pen in France and, in Australia, the member for Hotham (Mr Crean) hand in hand with the member for Oxley, show that opposing globalisation, through a brand of neoprotectionism, can gain some political support. It is actually a much more politically challenging task to go out and sell something notional, which is free trade, against something more concrete and tangible but also harmful, which is protectionism. The article does not minimise the significant dislocation that can occur as a result of globalisation. While the benefits of this process are distributed more evenly, those who pay a cost for freer trade are often clearly found.

The policy challenge is to sell, as this paper does, the benefits for Australia in globalisation and also to make sure that education, training and the social security net can minimise the impact for those who do not prosper in a globalised economy. As Rodrik says:

National policymakers must not retreat behind protectionist walls. Protectionism would be of limited help, and it would create its own social tensions. Policymakers ought instead to complement the external strategy of liberalisation with an internal strategy of compensation, training and social insurance for those groups who are most at risk.
Globalisation will continue to be influential with political, social and economic dimensions. Globalisation means that nations will have to account ultimately for poor fiscal and monetary policy.

One of the lessons from 1997 must be that, when the firestorm was engulfing the equity markets and the currencies of most Asian economies, Australia was only minimally affected. As Paul Kelly highlighted in the Australian of 26 November, `Asia's crisis reveals Australia's assets in terms of its economic fundamentals, its sophisticated financial system and its liberalisation of trade credentials.' The Howard government's lead by turning a $10 billion deficit into a budget surplus over three years helped Australia withstand that Asian turmoil.

The budget turnaround was opposed by Labor but without this improvement in our fiscal position not only would interest rates be higher but it is likely that our equity markets and exchange rate would have come under more pressure. Our low inflation, low mortgage interest rates and successful privatisation of Telstra are underpinned by policies that were opposed by the Australian Labor Party. The implementation of the Wallis inquiry recommendations will build on the reputation of our financial system in the key areas of consumer protection and prudential regulation. Australia has moved from Paul Keating's banana republic of 10 years ago to be a beacon in our region for fiscal prudence and financial sophistication.

In the section of the paper dealing with regional trade agreements I would like to sound a word of caution. There is nothing wrong with regional trade agreements per se. The closer economic relationship with New Zealand and APEC are both examples of regional agreements that Australia belongs to which do not undermine the World Trade Organisation or global free trade. They do not divert trade. However, customs unions or free trade areas which do not offer liberalisation on a most favoured nation basis, and are not open to entry for other nations, are likely to divert trade and actually undermine the principles of multilateral trade liberalisation.

BREAK.PARA: I believe that, while bilateral trade agreements may offer a tangible short‐term gain, the underlying principle for Australia's trade policy must be a commitment to multilateral trade liberalisation under the World Trade Organisation and also a commitment to the concept of open regionalism, which was defined by Ross Garnaut and Peter Drysdale at the ANU as embodied in organisations such as APEC, which do offer liberalisation on a most favoured nation basis to non‐participants of the regional organisation. The advantage of regional trade agreements may be a more wieldy, more rapid liberalisation, but it is important that they are WTO consistent and do not lead to any sort of trade diversion.

I think the white paper states very clearly and importantly what Australia's priorities will be as we approach the next century. It does offer a framework in a very transparent way to say what Australia will be prioritising in terms of our foreign policy. It is only a framework. It is a framework which we will work within. I commend the paper to the House.
Debate (on motion by Mr Anthony) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: The following answers to questions were circulated:

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Bevis, Arch, MP

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Special Minister of State, upon notice, on 25 August 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Further to questions Nos. 1803 (Hansard , 25 August 1997, page 6778) and 1804 (Hansard , 25 August 1997, page 6779), what procedures are in place to check and verify that requirements placed on private car hire firms are implemented.
(2) What action will be taken in relation to private hire car firms who fail to (a) adopt or (b) maintain required standards.

(3) What action will be taken in relation to private hire car firms which directly tout business from Comcar customers or which encourage Comcar customers to bypass Comcar altogether when making bookings.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Fahey, John, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The Special Minister of State has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: I am advised that:

(1) In addition to the requirements under Purchasing Australia's Hire Car Services (Chauffeur Driver) Common Use Agreement—Buyers Guide 20, COMCAR has tightened its requirements of contractors, particularly in regard to safety and security of passengers. COMCAR has briefed contractors about these additional requirements and has required all contractors to advise COMCAR of processes they have put in place to ensure that they comply with these requirements. In addition COMCAR continually monitors contractor performance and undertakes periodic visits to contractors.
(2) (a) and (b) Hire car contractors who fail to adopt or maintain the required standards will not be engaged by COMCAR.

(3) COMCAR will immediately investigate the matter, contact the hire car contractor direct and instigate corrective action. If such service failures continue, the contractor's priority or preference on the contract will be reviewed.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: McClelland, Robert, MP

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, upon notice, on 25 August 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: Are World War I veterans entitled to benefits which are not available to World War II veterans; if so, (a) what and (b) will he consider extending the benefits to all World War II veterans.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Scott, Bruce, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (a) Health Care Benefits

Currently, the Gold Card, which gives access to Veterans' Affairs health care benefits for all conditions whether service‐related or not, is available to veterans of the Australian defence forces who:
. served in World War I;
. were prisoners of war;
. are receiving a disability pension at or above 100% of the general rate;
. were receiving a disability pension for pulmonary tuberculosis before 2 November 1978;
. are receiving a disability pension at or above 50% of the general rate and are also receiving any amount of service pension;
. are receiving an additional amount under section 27 of the Veterans' Entitlements Act 1986 (VEA) for specific service‐related amputations or blindness in one eye;
. are receiving a service pension and satisfy the treatment benefits eligibility income and assets tests;
. are receiving a service pension and who are permanently blinded in both eyes; or
. are returned ex‐servicewomen of World War II, that is, who served in the Australian Defence Force between 3 September 1939 and 29 October 1945 and incurred danger from hostile enemy forces.
Pensions and Allowances

There is no difference in the eligibility criteria for pensions payable to both World War I and World War II veterans. The same applies to the eligibility criteria for all allowances except the telephone allowance.

The telephone allowance is currently $59.20 per year, paid in quarterly instalments of $15.40. In respect of World War I veterans the telephone allowance is paid at $42.50 per quarter representing the entire cost of the telephone rental.

Eligibility for the telephone allowance equivalent to the entire telephone rental charge was extended to World War I veterans in recognition of their service and in recognition of the extreme age and frailty of these veterans and the fact that they need access to communication facilities in times of emergency.

The Government appreciates that some veterans of World War II, and later conflicts, are also in failing health and need access to emergency alert devices. Such devices are already available to veterans on a needs basis through my Department.

(b) The Federal Government is always willing to consider the merits of requests for extending benefits. Various Governments over the years have extended Veterans' Affairs health care benefits to an increasing range of veterans of the Australian defence forces.

(2) Is there a policy to enforce counselling or other action for Members and Senators against whom informal complaints are lodged; if so, what is it; if not, (a) why and (b) will he consider such a policy.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Fahey, John, MP

ANSWER.PARA: (1) (a) none; (b) not applicable; (c) not applicable; (d) not applicable.
